Private Geometric Median in Nearly-Linear Time

Syamantak Kumar University of Texas at Austin, syamantak@utexas.edu    Daogao Liu Google Research, liudaogao@gmail.com    Kevin Tian University of Texas at Austin, kjtian@cs.utexas.edu    Chutong Yang University of Texas at Austin, cyang98@utexas.edu
Abstract

Estimating the geometric median of a dataset is a robust counterpart to mean estimation, and is a fundamental problem in computational geometry. Recently, [HSU24] gave an (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)( italic_ϵ , italic_δ )-differentially private algorithm obtaining an α𝛼\alphaitalic_α-multiplicative approximation to the geometric median objective, 1n∑i∈[n]∥⋅−𝐱i∥\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i\in[n]}\|\cdot-\mathbf{x}_{i}\|divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ ⋅ - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥, given a dataset 𝒟:={𝐱i}i∈[n]⊂ℝdassign𝒟subscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖𝑖delimited-[]𝑛superscriptℝ𝑑\mathcal{D}:=\{\mathbf{x}_{i}\}_{i\in[n]}\subset\mathbb{R}^{d}caligraphic_D := { bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⊂ roman_ℝ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Their algorithm requires n≳d⋅1α⁢ϵgreater-than-or-equivalent-to𝑛⋅𝑑1𝛼italic-ϵn\gtrsim\sqrt{d}\cdot\frac{1}{\alpha\epsilon}italic_n ≳ square-root start_ARG italic_d end_ARG ⋅ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_α italic_ϵ end_ARG samples, which they prove is information-theoretically optimal. This result is surprising because its error scales with the effective radius of 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D (i.e., of a ball capturing most points), rather than the worst-case radius. We give an improved algorithm that obtains the same approximation quality, also using n≳d⋅1α⁢ϵgreater-than-or-equivalent-to𝑛⋅𝑑1𝛼italic-ϵn\gtrsim\sqrt{d}\cdot\frac{1}{\alpha\epsilon}italic_n ≳ square-root start_ARG italic_d end_ARG ⋅ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_α italic_ϵ end_ARG samples, but in time O~⁢(n⁢d+dα2)~𝑂𝑛𝑑𝑑superscript𝛼2\widetilde{O}(nd+\frac{d}{\alpha^{2}})over~ start_ARG italic_O end_ARG ( italic_n italic_d + divide start_ARG italic_d end_ARG start_ARG italic_α start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ). Our runtime is nearly-linear, plus the cost of the cheapest non-private first-order method due to [CLM+16]. To achieve our results, we use subsampling and geometric aggregation tools inspired by FriendlyCore [TCK+22] to speed up the “warm start” component of the [HSU24] algorithm, combined with a careful custom analysis of DP-SGD’s sensitivity for the geometric median objective.

1 Introduction

The geometric median problem, also known as the Fermat-Weber problem, is one of the oldest problems in computational geometry. In this problem, we are given a dataset 𝒟={𝐱i}i∈[n]⊂ℝd𝒟subscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖𝑖delimited-[]𝑛superscriptℝ𝑑\mathcal{D}=\{\mathbf{x}_{i}\}_{i\in[n]}\subset\mathbb{R}^{d}caligraphic_D = { bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⊂ roman_ℝ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and our goal is to find a point 𝐱⋆∈ℝdsubscript𝐱⋆superscriptℝ𝑑\mathbf{x}_{\star}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ roman_ℝ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT that minimizes the average Euclidean distance to points in the dataset:

𝐱⋆∈arg⁡min𝐱∈ℝd⁡f𝒟⁢(𝐱), where ⁢f𝒟⁢(𝐱):=1n⁢∑i∈[n]‖𝐱−𝐱i‖.formulae-sequencesubscript𝐱⋆subscript𝐱superscriptℝ𝑑subscript𝑓𝒟𝐱assign where subscript𝑓𝒟𝐱1𝑛subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛norm𝐱subscript𝐱𝑖\mathbf{x}_{\star}\in\arg\min_{\mathbf{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}f_{\mathcal{D}}(% \mathbf{x}),\text{ where }f_{\mathcal{D}}(\mathbf{x}):=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i\in[n% ]}\|\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}_{i}\|.bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ roman_arg roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∈ roman_ℝ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) , where italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) := divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ bold_x - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ . (1)

This problem has received widespread interest due to its applications in high-dimensional statistics. In particular, the geometric median of a dataset 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D enjoys robustness properties that the mean (i.e., 1n⁢∑i∈[n]𝐱i1𝑛subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛subscript𝐱𝑖\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i\in[n]}\mathbf{x}_{i}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the minimizer of 1n⁢∑i∈[n]∥𝐱−𝐱i∥21𝑛subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛superscriptdelimited-∥∥𝐱subscript𝐱𝑖2\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i\in[n]}\left\lVert\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}_{i}\right\rVert^{2}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ bold_x - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT) does not. For example, it is known (cf. Lemma 4) that if greater than half of 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D lies within a distance r𝑟ritalic_r of some 𝐱¯∈ℝd¯𝐱superscriptℝ𝑑\bar{\mathbf{x}}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}over¯ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG ∈ roman_ℝ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, then the geometric median lies within O⁢(r)𝑂𝑟O(r)italic_O ( italic_r ) of 𝐱¯¯𝐱\bar{\mathbf{x}}over¯ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG. Thus, the geometric median provides strong estimation guarantees even when 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D contains outliers. This is in contrast to simpler estimators such as the mean, which can be arbitrarily corrupted by a single outlier. As a result, studying the properties and computational aspects of the geometric median has a long history, see e.g., [Web29, LR91] for some famous examples.

In this paper, we provide improved algorithms for estimating (1) subject to (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)( italic_ϵ , italic_δ )-differential privacy (DP, Definition 1), the de facto notion of provable privacy in modern machine learning. Privately computing the geometric median naturally fits into a recent line of work on designing DP algorithms in the presence of outliers. To explain the challenge of such problems, the definition of DP implies that the privacy-preserving guarantee must hold for worst-case datasets. This stringent definition affords DP a variety of desirable properties, most notably composition of private mechanisms (cf. [DR14], Section 3.5). However, it also begets challenges: for example, estimating the empirical mean of 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D subject to (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)( italic_ϵ , italic_δ )-DP necessarily results in error scaling ∝Rproportional-toabsent𝑅\propto R∝ italic_R, the diameter of the dataset (cf. Section 5, [BST14]). Moreover, the worst-case nature of DP is at odds with typical average-case machine learning settings, where most (or all) of 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D is drawn from a distribution that we wish to learn about. From an algorithm design standpoint, the question follows: how do we design methods that provide privacy guarantees for worst-case data, but also yield improved utility guarantees for (mostly) average-case data?

Such questions have been successfully addressed for various statistical tasks in recent work, including parameter estimation [BD14, KV17, BKSW19, DFM+20, BDKU20, BGS+21, AL22, LKJO22, KDH23, BHS23], clustering [NRS07, NSV16, CKM+21, TCK+22], and more. However, existing approaches for estimating (1) (even non-privately) are based on iterative optimization methods, as the geometric median does not admit a simple, closed-form solution. Much of the DP optimization toolkit is exactly plagued by the aforementioned “worst-case sensitivity” issues, e.g., lower bounds for general stochastic optimization problems again scale with the domain size. This is troubling in the context of (1), because a major appeal of the geometric median is its robustness: its error should not be significantly affected by any small subset of the data. Privately estimating the geometric median thus poses an interesting technical challenge, beyond its potential appeal as a subroutine in downstream robust algorithms.

To explain the distinction between worst-case and average-case error rates in the context of (1), we introduce the following helpful notation: for all quantiles τ∈[0,1]𝜏01\tau\in[0,1]italic_τ ∈ [ 0 , 1 ], we let

r(τ):=arg⁡minr≥0⁡{∑i∈[n]𝕀∥𝐱i−𝐱⋆∥≤r≥τ⁢n}, where ⁢𝐱⋆:=arg⁡min𝐱∈ℝd⁡1n⁢∑i∈[n]∥𝐱−𝐱i∥,formulae-sequenceassignsuperscript𝑟𝜏subscript𝑟0subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛subscript𝕀delimited-∥∥subscript𝐱𝑖subscript𝐱⋆𝑟𝜏𝑛assign where subscript𝐱⋆subscript𝐱superscriptℝ𝑑1𝑛subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛delimited-∥∥𝐱subscript𝐱𝑖r^{(\tau)}:=\arg\min_{r\geq 0}\left\{\sum_{i\in[n]}\mathbb{I}_{\left\lVert% \mathbf{x}_{i}-\mathbf{x}_{\star}\right\rVert\leq r}\geq\tau n\right\},\text{ % where }\mathbf{x}_{\star}:=\arg\min_{\mathbf{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}\frac{1}{n}% \sum_{i\in[n]}\left\lVert\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}_{i}\right\rVert,italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_τ ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := roman_arg roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r ≥ 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT { ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_𝕀 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ ≤ italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ italic_τ italic_n } , where bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := roman_arg roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∈ roman_ℝ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ bold_x - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ , (2)

when 𝒟={𝐱i}i∈[n]⊂ℝd𝒟subscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖𝑖delimited-[]𝑛superscriptℝ𝑑\mathcal{D}=\{\mathbf{x}_{i}\}_{i\in[n]}\subset\mathbb{R}^{d}caligraphic_D = { bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⊂ roman_ℝ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is clear from context. In other words, r(τ)superscript𝑟𝜏r^{(\tau)}italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_τ ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the smallest radius describing a ball around the geometric median 𝐱⋆subscript𝐱⋆\mathbf{x}_{\star}bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT containing at least τ⁢n𝜏𝑛\tau nitalic_τ italic_n points in 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D. We also use R𝑅Ritalic_R to denote an a priori overall domain size bound, where we are guaranteed that 𝒟⊂𝔹d⁢(R)𝒟superscript𝔹𝑑𝑅\mathcal{D}\subset\mathbb{B}^{d}(R)caligraphic_D ⊂ roman_𝔹 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_R ). Note that in general, it is possible for, e.g., r(0.9)≪Rmuch-less-thansuperscript𝑟0.9𝑅r^{(0.9)}\ll Ritalic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0.9 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≪ italic_R if ≈10%absentpercent10\approx 10\%≈ 10 % of 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D consists of outliers with atypical norms. Due to the robust nature of the geometric median (i.e., the aforementioned Lemma 4), a natural target is estimation error scaling with the “effective radius” r(τ)superscript𝑟𝜏r^{(\tau)}italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_τ ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for some quantile τ∈(0.5,1)𝜏0.51\tau\in(0.5,1)italic_τ ∈ ( 0.5 , 1 ). This is a much stronger guarantee than the error rates ∝Rproportional-toabsent𝑅\propto R∝ italic_R that typical DP optimization methods give.

Because a simple argument (Lemma 3) shows that r(τ)=O⁢(f𝒟⁢(𝐱⋆))superscript𝑟𝜏𝑂subscript𝑓𝒟subscript𝐱⋆r^{(\tau)}=O(f_{\mathcal{D}}(\mathbf{x}_{\star}))italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_τ ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_O ( italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) for all τ<1𝜏1\tau<1italic_τ < 1, in this introduction our goal will be to approximate the minimizer of (1) to additive error α⁢f𝒟⁢(𝐱⋆)𝛼subscript𝑓𝒟subscript𝐱⋆\alpha f_{\mathcal{D}}(\mathbf{x}_{\star})italic_α italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) for some α∈(0,1)𝛼01\alpha\in(0,1)italic_α ∈ ( 0 , 1 ), i.e., to give α𝛼\alphaitalic_α-multiplicative error guarantees on optimizing f𝒟subscript𝑓𝒟f_{\mathcal{D}}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.111Our results, as well as those of [HSU24], in fact give stronger additive error bounds of α⁢r(τ)𝛼superscript𝑟𝜏\alpha r^{(\tau)}italic_α italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_τ ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for any fixed τ∈(0.5,1)𝜏0.51\tau\in(0.5,1)italic_τ ∈ ( 0.5 , 1 ). Again, datasets with outliers may have f𝒟⁢(𝐱⋆)≪Rmuch-less-thansubscript𝑓𝒟subscript𝐱⋆𝑅f_{\mathcal{D}}(\mathbf{x}_{\star})\ll Ritalic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ≪ italic_R, so this goal is beyond the reach of naïvely applying DP optimization methods.

In a recent exciting work, [HSU24] bypassed this obstacle and obtained such private multiplicative approximations to the geometric median, and with near-optimal sample complexity. Assuming that 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D has size n≳d⋅1α⁢ϵgreater-than-or-equivalent-to𝑛⋅𝑑1𝛼italic-ϵn\gtrsim\sqrt{d}\cdot\frac{1}{\alpha\epsilon}italic_n ≳ square-root start_ARG italic_d end_ARG ⋅ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_α italic_ϵ end_ARG,222In this introduction only, we use O~,≲,≳~𝑂less-than-or-similar-togreater-than-or-equivalent-to\widetilde{O},\lesssim,\gtrsimover~ start_ARG italic_O end_ARG , ≲ , ≳ to hide polylogarithmic factors in problem parameters, i.e., d𝑑ditalic_d, 1α1𝛼\frac{1}{\alpha}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_α end_ARG, 1ϵ1italic-ϵ\frac{1}{\epsilon}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_ϵ end_ARG, 1δ1𝛿\frac{1}{\delta}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG, and Rr𝑅𝑟\frac{R}{r}divide start_ARG italic_R end_ARG start_ARG italic_r end_ARG, where 𝒟⊆𝔹d⁢(R)𝒟superscript𝔹𝑑𝑅\mathcal{D}\subseteq\mathbb{B}^{d}(R)caligraphic_D ⊆ roman_𝔹 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_R ) and r≤r(0.9)𝑟superscript𝑟0.9r\leq r^{(0.9)}italic_r ≤ italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0.9 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Our formal theorem statements explicitly state our dependences on all parameters. [HSU24] gave two algorithms for estimating (1) to α𝛼\alphaitalic_α-multiplicative error (cf. Appendix A). They also proved a matching lower bound, showing that this many samples is information-theoretically necessary.333Intuitively, we require α≈d−1/2𝛼superscript𝑑12\alpha\approx d^{-1/2}italic_α ≈ italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to obtain nontrivial mean estimation when 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D consists of i.i.d. Gaussian data (as a typical radius is ≈dabsent𝑑\approx\sqrt{d}≈ square-root start_ARG italic_d end_ARG), matching known sample complexity lower bounds of ≈dϵabsent𝑑italic-ϵ\approx\frac{d}{\epsilon}≈ divide start_ARG italic_d end_ARG start_ARG italic_ϵ end_ARG for Gaussian mean estimation [KLSU19]. From both a theoretical and practical perspective, the main outstanding question left by [HSU24] is that of computational efficiency: in particular, the [HSU24] algorithms ran in time O~⁢(n2⁢d+n3⁢ϵ2)~𝑂superscript𝑛2𝑑superscript𝑛3superscriptitalic-ϵ2\widetilde{O}(n^{2}d+n^{3}\epsilon^{2})over~ start_ARG italic_O end_ARG ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d + italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) or O~⁢(n2⁢d+n⁢d2+d4.372)~𝑂superscript𝑛2𝑑𝑛superscript𝑑2superscript𝑑4.372\widetilde{O}(n^{2}d+nd^{2}+d^{4.372})over~ start_ARG italic_O end_ARG ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d + italic_n italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4.372 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). This leaves a significant gap between algorithms for privately solving (1), and their counterparts in the non-private setting, where [CLM+16] showed that (1) could be approximated to α𝛼\alphaitalic_α-multiplicative error in nearly-linear time O~⁢(min⁡(n⁢d,dα2))~𝑂𝑛𝑑𝑑superscript𝛼2\widetilde{O}(\min(nd,\frac{d}{\alpha^{2}}))over~ start_ARG italic_O end_ARG ( roman_min ( italic_n italic_d , divide start_ARG italic_d end_ARG start_ARG italic_α start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ) ).

1.1 Our results

Our main contribution is a faster algorithm for privately approximating (1) to α𝛼\alphaitalic_α-multiplicative error.

Theorem 1 (informal, see Theorem 4).

Let 𝒟={𝐱i}i∈[n]⊂𝔹d⁢(R)𝒟subscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖𝑖delimited-[]𝑛superscript𝔹𝑑𝑅\mathcal{D}=\{\mathbf{x}_{i}\}_{i\in[n]}\subset\mathbb{B}^{d}(R)caligraphic_D = { bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⊂ roman_𝔹 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_R ) for R>0𝑅0R>0italic_R > 0, 0<r≤r(0.9)0𝑟superscript𝑟0.90<r\leq r^{(0.9)}0 < italic_r ≤ italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0.9 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and (α,ϵ,δ)∈[0,1]3𝛼italic-ϵ𝛿superscript013(\alpha,\epsilon,\delta)\in[0,1]^{3}( italic_α , italic_ϵ , italic_δ ) ∈ [ 0 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. There is an (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)( italic_ϵ , italic_δ )-DP algorithm that returns 𝐱^^𝐱\hat{\mathbf{x}}over^ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG such that with probability ≥1−δabsent1𝛿\geq 1-\delta≥ 1 - italic_δ, f𝒟⁢(𝐱^)≤(1+α)⁢f𝒟⁢(𝐱⋆)subscript𝑓𝒟^𝐱1𝛼subscript𝑓𝒟subscript𝐱⋆f_{\mathcal{D}}(\hat{\mathbf{x}})\leq(1+\alpha)f_{\mathcal{D}}(\mathbf{x}_{% \star})italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over^ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG ) ≤ ( 1 + italic_α ) italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), assuming n≳dα⁢ϵgreater-than-or-equivalent-to𝑛𝑑𝛼italic-ϵn\gtrsim\frac{\sqrt{d}}{\alpha\epsilon}italic_n ≳ divide start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_d end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG italic_α italic_ϵ end_ARG. The algorithm runs in time O~⁢(n⁢d+dα2)~𝑂𝑛𝑑𝑑superscript𝛼2\widetilde{O}(nd+\frac{d}{\alpha^{2}})over~ start_ARG italic_O end_ARG ( italic_n italic_d + divide start_ARG italic_d end_ARG start_ARG italic_α start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ).

To briefly explain Theorem 1’s statement, it uses a priori knowledge of 0<r<R0𝑟𝑅0<r<R0 < italic_r < italic_R such that R𝑅Ritalic_R upper bounds the domain size of 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D, and r𝑟ritalic_r lower bounds the “effective radius” r(0.9)superscript𝑟0.9r^{(0.9)}italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0.9 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. However, its runtime only depends polylogarithmically on the aspect ratio Rr𝑅𝑟\frac{R}{r}divide start_ARG italic_R end_ARG start_ARG italic_r end_ARG, rather than polynomially (as naïve DP optimization methods would); we also remark that our sample complexity is independent of Rr𝑅𝑟\frac{R}{r}divide start_ARG italic_R end_ARG start_ARG italic_r end_ARG.

The runtime of Theorem 1 is nearly-linear in the regime n≳1α2greater-than-or-equivalent-to𝑛1superscript𝛼2n\gtrsim\frac{1}{\alpha^{2}}italic_n ≳ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_α start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG (e.g., if d⋅1ϵ≳1αgreater-than-or-equivalent-to⋅𝑑1italic-ϵ1𝛼\sqrt{d}\cdot\frac{1}{\epsilon}\gtrsim\frac{1}{\alpha}square-root start_ARG italic_d end_ARG ⋅ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_ϵ end_ARG ≳ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_α end_ARG), but more generally it does incur an additive overhead of dα2𝑑superscript𝛼2\frac{d}{\alpha^{2}}divide start_ARG italic_d end_ARG start_ARG italic_α start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG. This overhead matches the fastest non-private first-order method for approximating (1) to α𝛼\alphaitalic_α-multiplicative error, due to [CLM+16]. We note that [CLM+16] also gave a custom second-order interior-point method, that non-privately solves (1) in time O~⁢(n⁢d)~𝑂𝑛𝑑\widetilde{O}(nd)over~ start_ARG italic_O end_ARG ( italic_n italic_d ), i.e., with polylogarithmic dependence on 1α1𝛼\frac{1}{\alpha}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_α end_ARG. We leave removing this additive runtime term in the DP setting, or proving this is impossible in concrete query models, as a challenging question for future work.

Our algorithm follows a roadmap given by [HSU24], who split their algorithm into two phases: an initial “warm start” phase that computes an O⁢(1)𝑂1O(1)italic_O ( 1 )-multiplicative approximation of the geometric median, and a secondary “boosting” phase that uses iterative optimization methods to improve the warm start to an α𝛼\alphaitalic_α-multiplicative approximation. The role of the warm start is to improve the domain size of the boosting phase to scale with the effective radius. However, both the warm start and the boosting phases of [HSU24] required superlinear ≈n2⁢dabsentsuperscript𝑛2𝑑\approx n^{2}d≈ italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d time. Our improvement to the warm start phase of the [HSU24] is quite simple, and may be of independent interest, so we provide a self-contained statement here.

Theorem 2 (informal, see Theorem 3).

Let 𝒟={𝐱i}i∈[n]⊂𝔹d⁢(R)𝒟subscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖𝑖delimited-[]𝑛superscript𝔹𝑑𝑅\mathcal{D}=\{\mathbf{x}_{i}\}_{i\in[n]}\subset\mathbb{B}^{d}(R)caligraphic_D = { bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⊂ roman_𝔹 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_R ) for R>0𝑅0R>0italic_R > 0, 0<r≤r(0.9)0𝑟superscript𝑟0.90<r\leq r^{(0.9)}0 < italic_r ≤ italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0.9 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and (ϵ,δ)∈[0,1]2italic-ϵ𝛿superscript012(\epsilon,\delta)\in[0,1]^{2}( italic_ϵ , italic_δ ) ∈ [ 0 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. There is an (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)( italic_ϵ , italic_δ )-DP algorithm that returns 𝐱^^𝐱\hat{\mathbf{x}}over^ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG such that with probability ≥1−δabsent1𝛿\geq 1-\delta≥ 1 - italic_δ, f𝒟⁢(𝐱^)=O⁢(f𝒟⁢(𝐱⋆))subscript𝑓𝒟^𝐱𝑂subscript𝑓𝒟subscript𝐱⋆f_{\mathcal{D}}(\hat{\mathbf{x}})=O(f_{\mathcal{D}}(\mathbf{x}_{\star}))italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over^ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG ) = italic_O ( italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ), assuming n≳dϵgreater-than-or-equivalent-to𝑛𝑑italic-ϵn\gtrsim\frac{\sqrt{d}}{\epsilon}italic_n ≳ divide start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_d end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG italic_ϵ end_ARG. The algorithm runs in time O~⁢(n⁢d)~𝑂𝑛𝑑\widetilde{O}(nd)over~ start_ARG italic_O end_ARG ( italic_n italic_d ).

1.2 Our techniques

As discussed previously, our algorithm employs a similar framework as [HSU24]. It is convenient to further split the warm start phase of the algorithm into two parts: finding an estimate r^^𝑟\hat{r}over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG of the effective radius of 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D, and finding an approximate centerpoint at distance O⁢(r^)𝑂^𝑟O(\hat{r})italic_O ( over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG ) from the geometric median 𝐱⋆subscript𝐱⋆\mathbf{x}_{\star}bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Radius estimation.

Our radius estimation algorithm is almost identical to that in [HSU24], Section 2.1, which uses the sparse vector technique (cf. Lemma 2) to detect the first time an estimate r^^𝑟\hat{r}over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG is such that most points have ≥34absent34\geq\frac{3}{4}≥ divide start_ARG 3 end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG of 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D at a distance of ≈r^absent^𝑟\approx\hat{r}≈ over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG. The estimate r^^𝑟\hat{r}over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG is geometrically updated over a grid of size O⁢(log⁡(Rr))𝑂𝑅𝑟O(\log(\frac{R}{r}))italic_O ( roman_log ( divide start_ARG italic_R end_ARG start_ARG italic_r end_ARG ) ). Naïvely implemented, this strategy takes ≳n2⁢dgreater-than-or-equivalent-toabsentsuperscript𝑛2𝑑\gtrsim n^{2}d≳ italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d time due to the need for pairwise distance comparisons (cf. Appendix A); even if dimesionality reduction techniques are used, this step appears to require Ω⁢(n2)Ωsuperscript𝑛2\Omega(n^{2})roman_Ω ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) time. We make a simple observation that a random sample of ≈log⁡(1δ)absent1𝛿\approx\log(\frac{1}{\delta})≈ roman_log ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG ) points from 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D is enough to determine whether a given point has ≫βmuch-greater-thanabsent𝛽\gg\beta≫ italic_β neighbors, or ≪γmuch-less-thanabsent𝛾\ll\gamma≪ italic_γ, for appropriate (constant) quantile thresholds β,γ𝛽𝛾\beta,\gammaitalic_β , italic_γ, which is enough to obtain an O~⁢(n⁢d)~𝑂𝑛𝑑\widetilde{O}(nd)over~ start_ARG italic_O end_ARG ( italic_n italic_d ) runtime.

Centerpoint estimation.

Our centerpoint estimation step departs from [HSU24], Section 2.2, who analyzed a custom variant of DP gradient descent with geometrically-decaying step sizes. We make the simple observation that directly applying the FriendlyCore algorithm of [HSU24] yields the same result. However, the standard implementation of FriendlyCore again requires Ω⁢(n2)Ωsuperscript𝑛2\Omega(n^{2})roman_Ω ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) time to estimate weights for each data point. We again show that FriendlyCore can be sped up to run in O~⁢(n⁢d)~𝑂𝑛𝑑\widetilde{O}(nd)over~ start_ARG italic_O end_ARG ( italic_n italic_d ) time (independently of Rr𝑅𝑟\frac{R}{r}divide start_ARG italic_R end_ARG start_ARG italic_r end_ARG) via weights estimated through subsampling. Our privacy proof of this subsampled variant is subtle, and based on an argument (Lemma 1) that couples our algorithm to an idealized algorithm that never fails to be private. We use this to account for the privacy loss due to the failure of our subsampling, i.e., if the estimates are inaccurate. We note that the [HSU24] algorithm for this step already ran in nearly-linear ≈n⁢d⁢log⁡(Rr)absent𝑛𝑑𝑅𝑟\approx nd\log(\frac{R}{r})≈ italic_n italic_d roman_log ( divide start_ARG italic_R end_ARG start_ARG italic_r end_ARG ) time, so we obtain an asymptotic improvement only if Rr𝑅𝑟\frac{R}{r}divide start_ARG italic_R end_ARG start_ARG italic_r end_ARG is large.

Boosting.

The most technically novel part of our algorithm is in the boosting phase, which takes as input a radius and centerpoint estimate from the previous steps, and outputs an α𝛼\alphaitalic_α-multiplicative approximation to (1). Like [HSU24], we use iterative optimization methods to implement this phase. However, a major bottleneck to a faster algorithm is the lack of a nearly-linear time DP solver for non-smooth empirical risk minimization (ERM) problems. Indeed, such O~⁢(1)~𝑂1\widetilde{O}(1)over~ start_ARG italic_O end_ARG ( 1 )-pass optimizers are known only when the objective is convex and sufficiently smooth [FKT20], or n≳d2greater-than-or-equivalent-to𝑛superscript𝑑2n\gtrsim d^{2}italic_n ≳ italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT samples are taken [CJJ+23]. This is an issue, because while computing the geometric median (1) is a convex ERM problem, it is non-smooth, and nontrivial multiplicative guarantees are possible even with n≈d𝑛𝑑n\approx\sqrt{d}italic_n ≈ square-root start_ARG italic_d end_ARG samples.

We give a custom analysis of DP-SGD, specifically catered to the (non-smooth) ERM objective (1). Our main contribution is a tighter sensitivity analysis of DP-SGD’s iterates, leveraging the structure of the geometric median. To motivate this observation, consider coupled algorithms with iterates 𝐳𝐳\mathbf{z}bold_z, 𝐳′superscript𝐳′\mathbf{z}^{\prime}bold_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, both taking gradient steps with respect to the subsampled function ∥⋅−𝐱i∥\left\lVert\cdot-\mathbf{x}_{i}\right\rVert∥ ⋅ - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ for some dataset element 𝐱i∈𝒟subscript𝐱𝑖𝒟\mathbf{x}_{i}\in\mathcal{D}bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_D. A simple calculation (12) shows these gradients are unit vectors 𝐮𝐮\mathbf{u}bold_u, 𝐮′superscript𝐮′\mathbf{u}^{\prime}bold_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, in the directions of 𝐳−𝐱i𝐳subscript𝐱𝑖\mathbf{z}-\mathbf{x}_{i}bold_z - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and 𝐳′−𝐱isuperscript𝐳′subscript𝐱𝑖\mathbf{z}^{\prime}-\mathbf{x}_{i}bold_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT respectively. It is not hard to formalize (Lemma 11) that updating 𝐳←𝐳−η⁢𝐮←𝐳𝐳𝜂𝐮\mathbf{z}\leftarrow\mathbf{z}-\eta\mathbf{u}bold_z ← bold_z - italic_η bold_u and 𝐳′←𝐳′−η⁢𝐮′←superscript𝐳′superscript𝐳′𝜂superscript𝐮′\mathbf{z}^{\prime}\leftarrow\mathbf{z}^{\prime}-\eta\mathbf{u}^{\prime}bold_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ← bold_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_η bold_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is always contractive, unless 𝐳,𝐳′𝐳superscript𝐳′\mathbf{z},\mathbf{z}^{\prime}bold_z , bold_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT were both already very close to 𝐱isubscript𝐱𝑖\mathbf{x}_{i}bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (and hence, each other) to begin with. We use this structural result to inductively control DP-SGD’s sensitivity, which lets us leverage a prior reduction from private optimization to stable optimization [FKT20].

Our result is the first we are aware of that obtains a nearly-linear runtime for DP-SGD on a structured non-smooth problem. We were inspired by [ALT24], who also gave faster runtimes for (smooth) DP optimization problems with outliers under further assumptions on the objective. We hope that our work motivates future DP optimization methods that harness problem structure for improved rates.

1.3 Related work

Differentially private convex optimization.

Differentially private convex optimization has been studied extensively for over a decade [CM08, KST12, BST14, KJ16, BFGT20, FKT20, BGN21, GLL22, GLL+23] and inspired the influential DP-SGD algorithm widely adopted in deep learning [ACG+16]. In the classic setting, where functions are assumed to be Lipschitz and defined over a convex domain of diameter R𝑅Ritalic_R, optimal rates have been achieved with linear dependence on R𝑅Ritalic_R [BFTGT19]. Recent years have seen significant advancements in optimizing the gradient complexity of DP stochastic convex optimization [FKT20, AFKT21, KLL21, ZTC22, CJJ+23, CCGT24]. Despite these efforts, a nearly-linear gradient complexity has only been established for sufficiently smooth functions [FKT20, ZTC22, CCGT24] and for non-smooth functions [CJJ+23] when the condition n≳dgreater-than-or-equivalent-to𝑛𝑑\sqrt{n}\gtrsim dsquare-root start_ARG italic_n end_ARG ≳ italic_d is satisfied.

Differential privacy with average-case data.

Adapting noise to the inherent properties of data, rather than catering to worst-case scenarios, is critical for making differential privacy practical in real-world applications. Several important approaches have emerged in this direction: smooth sensitivity frameworks [NRS07] that refine local sensitivity to make it private; instance optimality techniques [AD20] that provide tailored guarantees for specific datasets; methods with improved performance under distributional assumptions such as sub-Gaussian or heavy-tailed i.i.d. data [CWZ21, AL23, ALT24]; and data-dependent sensitivity computations that adapt during algorithm execution [ATMR21]. These approaches collectively represent the frontier in balancing privacy and utility beyond worst-case analyses. We view our work as another contribution towards this broader program.

2 Preliminaries

In this section, we collect preliminary results used throughout the paper. We define our notation in Section 2.1. We then formally state helper definitions and known tools from the literature on differential privacy and computing the geometric median in Sections 2.2 and 2.3 respectively.

2.1 Notation and probability basics

Throughout, vectors are denoted in lowercase boldface, and the all-zeroes and all-ones vectors in dimension d𝑑ditalic_d are respectively denoted 𝟎dsubscript0𝑑\mathbf{0}_{d}bold_0 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and 𝟏dsubscript1𝑑\mathbf{1}_{d}bold_1 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We use ∥⋅∥delimited-∥∥⋅\left\lVert\cdot\right\rVert∥ ⋅ ∥ to denote the Euclidean (ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) norm of a vector argument. We use [d]delimited-[]𝑑[d][ italic_d ] to denote {i∈ℕ∣1≤i≤d}conditional-set𝑖ℕ1𝑖𝑑\{i\in\mathbb{N}\mid 1\leq i\leq d\}{ italic_i ∈ roman_ℕ ∣ 1 ≤ italic_i ≤ italic_d }. We use 𝔹d⁢(𝝁,r):={𝐱∈ℝd∣∥𝐱−𝝁∥≤r}assignsuperscript𝔹𝑑𝝁𝑟conditional-set𝐱superscriptℝ𝑑delimited-∥∥𝐱𝝁𝑟\mathbb{B}^{d}(\boldsymbol{\mu},r):=\{\mathbf{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}\mid\left% \lVert\mathbf{x}-\boldsymbol{\mu}\right\rVert\leq r\}roman_𝔹 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_μ , italic_r ) := { bold_x ∈ roman_ℝ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∣ ∥ bold_x - bold_italic_μ ∥ ≤ italic_r } to denote the Euclidean ball of radius r>0𝑟0r>0italic_r > 0 around 𝝁∈ℝd𝝁superscriptℝ𝑑\boldsymbol{\mu}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}bold_italic_μ ∈ roman_ℝ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT; when 𝝁𝝁\boldsymbol{\mu}bold_italic_μ is unspecified, then 𝝁=𝟎d𝝁subscript0𝑑\boldsymbol{\mu}=\mathbf{0}_{d}bold_italic_μ = bold_0 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT by default. For a compact set 𝒦⊆ℝd𝒦superscriptℝ𝑑\mathcal{K}\subseteq\mathbb{R}^{d}caligraphic_K ⊆ roman_ℝ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we use 𝚷𝒦⁢(𝐱)subscript𝚷𝒦𝐱\boldsymbol{\Pi}_{\mathcal{K}}(\mathbf{x})bold_Π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) to denote the Euclidean projection arg⁡min𝐲∈𝒦⁡∥𝐱−𝐲∥subscript𝐲𝒦𝐱𝐲\arg\min_{\mathbf{y}\in\mathcal{K}}\left\lVert\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{y}\right\rVertroman_arg roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_y ∈ caligraphic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ bold_x - bold_y ∥.

We let 𝕀ℰsubscript𝕀ℰ\mathbb{I}_{\mathcal{E}}roman_𝕀 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denote the 00-1111 indicator random variable corresponding to an event ℰℰ\mathcal{E}caligraphic_E. For two densities μ,ν𝜇𝜈\mu,\nuitalic_μ , italic_ν on the same probability space ΩΩ\Omegaroman_Ω and α>1𝛼1\alpha>1italic_α > 1, we define the α𝛼\alphaitalic_α-Rényi divergence by:

Dα⁢(μ∥ν):=1α−1⁢log⁡(∫(μ⁢(ω)ν⁢(ω))α⁢ν⁢(ω)⁢d⁢ω).assignsubscript𝐷𝛼conditional𝜇𝜈1𝛼1superscript𝜇𝜔𝜈𝜔𝛼𝜈𝜔d𝜔D_{\alpha}(\mu\|\nu):=\frac{1}{\alpha-1}\log\left(\int\left(\frac{\mu(\omega)}% {\nu(\omega)}\right)^{\alpha}\nu(\omega)\textup{d}\omega\right).italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_α end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_μ ∥ italic_ν ) := divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_α - 1 end_ARG roman_log ( ∫ ( divide start_ARG italic_μ ( italic_ω ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_ν ( italic_ω ) end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_α end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ν ( italic_ω ) d italic_ω ) .

We use 𝒩⁢(𝝁,σ2⁢𝐈d)𝒩𝝁superscript𝜎2subscript𝐈𝑑\mathcal{N}(\boldsymbol{\mu},\sigma^{2}\mathbf{I}_{d})caligraphic_N ( bold_italic_μ , italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) to denote the multivariate normal distribution with mean 𝝁∈ℝd𝝁superscriptℝ𝑑\boldsymbol{\mu}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}bold_italic_μ ∈ roman_ℝ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and covariance σ2⁢𝐈dsuperscript𝜎2subscript𝐈𝑑\sigma^{2}\mathbf{I}_{d}italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where 𝐈dsubscript𝐈𝑑\mathbf{I}_{d}bold_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denotes the d×d𝑑𝑑d\times ditalic_d × italic_d identity matrix. We let 𝖫𝖺𝗉𝗅𝖺𝖼𝖾⁢(λ)𝖫𝖺𝗉𝗅𝖺𝖼𝖾𝜆\mathsf{Laplace}(\lambda)sansserif_Laplace ( italic_λ ) be the Laplace distribution with scale parameter λ≥0𝜆0\lambda\geq 0italic_λ ≥ 0, whose density is ∝exp⁡(−|⋅|λ)\propto\exp(-\frac{|\cdot|}{\lambda})∝ roman_exp ( - divide start_ARG | ⋅ | end_ARG start_ARG italic_λ end_ARG ). We let 𝖴𝗇𝗂𝖿⁢(S)𝖴𝗇𝗂𝖿𝑆\mathsf{Unif}(S)sansserif_Unif ( italic_S ) denote the uniform distribution over a set S𝑆Sitalic_S, and 𝖡𝖾𝗋𝗇⁢(p)𝖡𝖾𝗋𝗇𝑝\mathsf{Bern}(p)sansserif_Bern ( italic_p ) denote the Bernoulli distribution taking on values {0,1}01\{0,1\}{ 0 , 1 } with mean p∈[0,1]𝑝01p\in[0,1]italic_p ∈ [ 0 , 1 ]. We refer to a product distribution consisting of k𝑘kitalic_k i.i.d. copies of a base distribution 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D by 𝒟⊗ksuperscript𝒟tensor-productabsent𝑘\mathcal{D}^{\otimes k}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊗ italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. We also use the bounded Laplace distribution with parameters λ,τ≥0𝜆𝜏0\lambda,\tau\geq 0italic_λ , italic_τ ≥ 0, denoted 𝖡𝗈𝗎𝗇𝖽𝖾𝖽𝖫𝖺𝗉𝗅𝖺𝖼𝖾⁢(λ,τ)𝖡𝗈𝗎𝗇𝖽𝖾𝖽𝖫𝖺𝗉𝗅𝖺𝖼𝖾𝜆𝜏\mathsf{BoundedLaplace}(\lambda,\tau)sansserif_BoundedLaplace ( italic_λ , italic_τ ), which is the distribution of X∼𝖫𝖺𝗉𝗅𝖺𝖼𝖾⁢(λ)similar-to𝑋𝖫𝖺𝗉𝗅𝖺𝖼𝖾𝜆X\sim\mathsf{Laplace}(\lambda)italic_X ∼ sansserif_Laplace ( italic_λ ) conditioned on |X|≤τ𝑋𝜏|X|\leq\tau| italic_X | ≤ italic_τ.

Finally, we require the following standard bound on binomial concentration.

Fact 1 (Chernoff bound).

For all i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n]italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ], let Xi∼𝖡𝖾𝗋𝗇⁢(pi)similar-tosubscript𝑋𝑖𝖡𝖾𝗋𝗇subscript𝑝𝑖X_{i}\sim\mathsf{Bern}(p_{i})italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ sansserif_Bern ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) for some pi∈[0,1]subscript𝑝𝑖01p_{i}\in[0,1]italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ [ 0 , 1 ], and let μ:=∑i∈[n]piassign𝜇subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛subscript𝑝𝑖\mu:=\sum_{i\in[n]}p_{i}italic_μ := ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and μ^:=∑i∈[n]Xiassign^𝜇subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛subscript𝑋𝑖\hat{\mu}:=\sum_{i\in[n]}X_{i}over^ start_ARG italic_μ end_ARG := ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Then,

Pr⁡[μ^>(1+ϵ)⁢μ]≤exp⁡(−ϵ2⁢μ2+ϵ)⁢ for all ⁢ϵ≥0,Pr^𝜇1italic-ϵ𝜇superscriptitalic-ϵ2𝜇2italic-ϵ for all italic-ϵ0\displaystyle\Pr\left[\hat{\mu}>(1+\epsilon)\mu\right]\leq\exp\left(-\frac{% \epsilon^{2}\mu}{2+\epsilon}\right)\text{ for all }\epsilon\geq 0,roman_Pr [ over^ start_ARG italic_μ end_ARG > ( 1 + italic_ϵ ) italic_μ ] ≤ roman_exp ( - divide start_ARG italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_μ end_ARG start_ARG 2 + italic_ϵ end_ARG ) for all italic_ϵ ≥ 0 ,
Pr⁡[μ^<(1−ϵ)⁢μ]≤exp⁡(−ϵ2⁢μ2)⁢ for all ⁢ϵ∈(0,1).Pr^𝜇1italic-ϵ𝜇superscriptitalic-ϵ2𝜇2 for all italic-ϵ01\displaystyle\Pr\left[\hat{\mu}<(1-\epsilon)\mu\right]\leq\exp\left(-\frac{% \epsilon^{2}\mu}{2}\right)\text{ for all }\epsilon\in(0,1).roman_Pr [ over^ start_ARG italic_μ end_ARG < ( 1 - italic_ϵ ) italic_μ ] ≤ roman_exp ( - divide start_ARG italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_μ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) for all italic_ϵ ∈ ( 0 , 1 ) .

2.2 Differential privacy

Let 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}caligraphic_X be some domain, and let 𝒟∈𝒳n𝒟superscript𝒳𝑛\mathcal{D}\in\mathcal{X}^{n}caligraphic_D ∈ caligraphic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be a dataset consisting of n𝑛nitalic_n elements from 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}caligraphic_X. We say that two datasets 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D, 𝒟′∈𝒳nsuperscript𝒟′superscript𝒳𝑛\mathcal{D}^{\prime}\in\mathcal{X}^{n}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are neighboring if their symmetric difference has size 1111, i.e., they differ in a single element. We use the following definition of differential privacy in this paper.

Definition 1 (Differential privacy).

Let (ϵ,δ)∈[0,1]2italic-ϵ𝛿superscript012(\epsilon,\delta)\in[0,1]^{2}( italic_ϵ , italic_δ ) ∈ [ 0 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.444In principle, the privacy parameter ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilonitalic_ϵ can be larger than 1111. However, in this paper, sample complexities are unaffected up to constants for any ϵ≥1italic-ϵ1\epsilon\geq 1italic_ϵ ≥ 1 if we simply obtain (1,δ)1𝛿(1,\delta)( 1 , italic_δ )-DP guarantees rather than (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)( italic_ϵ , italic_δ )-DP guarantees, which are only stronger. Thus we state all results for ϵ∈[0,1]italic-ϵ01\epsilon\in[0,1]italic_ϵ ∈ [ 0 , 1 ] for convenience, which simplifies some bounds. We say that a randomized algorithm 𝒜:𝒳n→Ω:𝒜→superscript𝒳𝑛Ω\mathcal{A}:\mathcal{X}^{n}\to\Omegacaligraphic_A : caligraphic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → roman_Ω satisfies (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)( italic_ϵ , italic_δ )-differential privacy (or, is (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)( italic_ϵ , italic_δ )-DP) if for all events ℰ⊆ΩℰΩ\mathcal{E}\subseteq\Omegacaligraphic_E ⊆ roman_Ω, and for all neighboring datasets 𝒟,𝒟′∈𝒳n𝒟superscript𝒟′superscript𝒳𝑛\mathcal{D},\mathcal{D}^{\prime}\in\mathcal{X}^{n}caligraphic_D , caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we have

Pr⁡[𝒜⁢(𝒟)∈ℰ]≤exp⁡(ϵ)⁢Pr⁡[𝒜⁢(𝒟′)∈ℰ]+δ.Pr𝒜𝒟ℰitalic-ϵPr𝒜superscript𝒟′ℰ𝛿\Pr\left[\mathcal{A}(\mathcal{D})\in\mathcal{E}\right]\leq\exp(\epsilon)\Pr% \left[\mathcal{A}(\mathcal{D}^{\prime})\in\mathcal{E}\right]+\delta.roman_Pr [ caligraphic_A ( caligraphic_D ) ∈ caligraphic_E ] ≤ roman_exp ( italic_ϵ ) roman_Pr [ caligraphic_A ( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ∈ caligraphic_E ] + italic_δ .

DP algorithms satisfy basic composition (Theorem B.1, [DR14]), i.e., if 𝒜1:𝒳n→Ω1:subscript𝒜1→superscript𝒳𝑛subscriptΩ1\mathcal{A}_{1}:\mathcal{X}^{n}\to\Omega_{1}caligraphic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : caligraphic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → roman_Ω start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is (ϵ1,δ1)subscriptitalic-ϵ1subscript𝛿1(\epsilon_{1},\delta_{1})( italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )-DP and 𝒜2:𝒳n×Ω1→Ω2:subscript𝒜2→superscript𝒳𝑛subscriptΩ1subscriptΩ2\mathcal{A}_{2}:\mathcal{X}^{n}\times\Omega_{1}\to\Omega_{2}caligraphic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : caligraphic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT × roman_Ω start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT → roman_Ω start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is (ϵ2,δ2)subscriptitalic-ϵ2subscript𝛿2(\epsilon_{2},\delta_{2})( italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )-DP, then running 𝒜2subscript𝒜2\mathcal{A}_{2}caligraphic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT on 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D and the output of 𝒜1⁢(𝒟)subscript𝒜1𝒟\mathcal{A}_{1}(\mathcal{D})caligraphic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_D ) is (ϵ1+ϵ2,δ1+δ2)subscriptitalic-ϵ1subscriptitalic-ϵ2subscript𝛿1subscript𝛿2(\epsilon_{1}+\epsilon_{2},\delta_{1}+\delta_{2})( italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )-DP. We next state the Gaussian mechanism. Recall that if 𝐯:𝒳n→ℝk:𝐯→superscript𝒳𝑛superscriptℝ𝑘\mathbf{v}:\mathcal{X}^{n}\to\mathbb{R}^{k}bold_v : caligraphic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → roman_ℝ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a vector-valued function of a dataset, we say 𝐯𝐯\mathbf{v}bold_v has sensitivity ΔΔ\Deltaroman_Δ if for all neighboring 𝒟,𝒟′∈𝒳n𝒟superscript𝒟′superscript𝒳𝑛\mathcal{D},\mathcal{D}^{\prime}\in\mathcal{X}^{n}caligraphic_D , caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we have ∥𝐯⁢(𝒟)−𝐯⁢(𝒟′)∥≤Δdelimited-∥∥𝐯𝒟𝐯superscript𝒟′Δ\left\lVert\mathbf{v}(\mathcal{D})-\mathbf{v}(\mathcal{D}^{\prime})\right% \rVert\leq\Delta∥ bold_v ( caligraphic_D ) - bold_v ( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ∥ ≤ roman_Δ.

Fact 2 (Theorem A.1, [DR14]).

Let 𝐯:𝒳n→ℝk:𝐯→superscript𝒳𝑛superscriptℝ𝑘\mathbf{v}:\mathcal{X}^{n}\to\mathbb{R}^{k}bold_v : caligraphic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → roman_ℝ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT have sensitivity ΔΔ\Deltaroman_Δ, and let (ϵ,δ)∈[0,1]2italic-ϵ𝛿superscript012(\epsilon,\delta)\in[0,1]^{2}( italic_ϵ , italic_δ ) ∈ [ 0 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Then, drawing a sample from 𝒩⁢(𝐯⁢(𝒟),σ2⁢𝐈k)𝒩𝐯𝒟superscript𝜎2subscript𝐈𝑘\mathcal{N}(\mathbf{v}(\mathcal{D}),\sigma^{2}\mathbf{I}_{k})caligraphic_N ( bold_v ( caligraphic_D ) , italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)( italic_ϵ , italic_δ )-DP, for any σ≥2⁢Δϵ⋅log⁡(2δ)𝜎⋅2Δitalic-ϵ2𝛿\sigma\geq\frac{2\Delta}{\epsilon}\cdot\sqrt{\log(\frac{2}{\delta})}italic_σ ≥ divide start_ARG 2 roman_Δ end_ARG start_ARG italic_ϵ end_ARG ⋅ square-root start_ARG roman_log ( divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG ) end_ARG.

We also require the bounded Laplace mechanism, which is known to give the following guarantee.

Fact 3 (Lemma 9, [ALT24]).

Let s:𝒳n→ℝ:𝑠→superscript𝒳𝑛ℝs:\mathcal{X}^{n}\to\mathbb{R}italic_s : caligraphic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → roman_ℝ have sensitivity ΔΔ\Deltaroman_Δ, and let (ϵ,δ)∈[0,1]2italic-ϵ𝛿superscript012(\epsilon,\delta)\in[0,1]^{2}( italic_ϵ , italic_δ ) ∈ [ 0 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Then, drawing ξ∼𝖡𝗈𝗎𝗇𝖽𝖾𝖽𝖫𝖺𝗉𝗅𝖺𝖼𝖾⁢(Δϵ,τ)similar-to𝜉𝖡𝗈𝗎𝗇𝖽𝖾𝖽𝖫𝖺𝗉𝗅𝖺𝖼𝖾Δitalic-ϵ𝜏\xi\sim\mathsf{BoundedLaplace}(\frac{\Delta}{\epsilon},\tau)italic_ξ ∼ sansserif_BoundedLaplace ( divide start_ARG roman_Δ end_ARG start_ARG italic_ϵ end_ARG , italic_τ ) and outputting s⁢(𝒟)+ξ𝑠𝒟𝜉s(\mathcal{D})+\xiitalic_s ( caligraphic_D ) + italic_ξ is (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)( italic_ϵ , italic_δ )-DP for any τ≥Δϵ⁢log⁡(4δ)𝜏Δitalic-ϵ4𝛿\tau\geq\frac{\Delta}{\epsilon}\log(\frac{4}{\delta})italic_τ ≥ divide start_ARG roman_Δ end_ARG start_ARG italic_ϵ end_ARG roman_log ( divide start_ARG 4 end_ARG start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG ).

Fact 3 is proven in [ALT24] using a coupling argument, using the fact that 𝖡𝗈𝗎𝗇𝖽𝖾𝖽𝖫𝖺𝗉𝗅𝖺𝖼𝖾⁢(λ)𝖡𝗈𝗎𝗇𝖽𝖾𝖽𝖫𝖺𝗉𝗅𝖺𝖼𝖾𝜆\mathsf{BoundedLaplace}(\lambda)sansserif_BoundedLaplace ( italic_λ ) and 𝖫𝖺𝗉𝗅𝖺𝖼𝖾⁢(λ)𝖫𝖺𝗉𝗅𝖺𝖼𝖾𝜆\mathsf{Laplace}(\lambda)sansserif_Laplace ( italic_λ ) result in the same sample except with some probability. We appeal to this privacy proof technique several times in Section 3, so we state it explicitly here for convenience.

Lemma 1.

For (ϵ,δ)∈[0,1]2italic-ϵ𝛿superscript012(\epsilon,\delta)\in[0,1]^{2}( italic_ϵ , italic_δ ) ∈ [ 0 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, 𝒜:𝒳n→Ω:𝒜→superscript𝒳𝑛Ω\mathcal{A}:\mathcal{X}^{n}\to\Omegacaligraphic_A : caligraphic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → roman_Ω be an (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)( italic_ϵ , italic_δ )-DP algorithm, and let 𝒜¯¯𝒜\overline{\mathcal{A}}over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_A end_ARG be an algorithm such that on any input 𝒟∈𝒳n𝒟superscript𝒳𝑛\mathcal{D}\in\mathcal{X}^{n}caligraphic_D ∈ caligraphic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we have that the total variation distance between 𝒜⁢(𝒟)𝒜𝒟\mathcal{A}(\mathcal{D})caligraphic_A ( caligraphic_D ) and 𝒜¯⁢(𝒟)¯𝒜𝒟\overline{\mathcal{A}}(\mathcal{D})over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_A end_ARG ( caligraphic_D ) is at most δ′superscript𝛿′\delta^{\prime}italic_δ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Then, 𝒜¯¯𝒜\overline{\mathcal{A}}over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_A end_ARG is an (ϵ,δ+4⁢δ′)italic-ϵ𝛿4superscript𝛿′(\epsilon,\delta+4\delta^{\prime})( italic_ϵ , italic_δ + 4 italic_δ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )-DP algorithm.

Proof.

For neighboring datasets 𝒟,𝒟′𝒟superscript𝒟′\mathcal{D},\mathcal{D}^{\prime}caligraphic_D , caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and any event ℰ∈ΩℰΩ\mathcal{E}\in\Omegacaligraphic_E ∈ roman_Ω, we have that

Pr⁡[𝒜¯⁢(𝒟)∈ℰ]Pr¯𝒜𝒟ℰ\displaystyle\Pr\left[\overline{\mathcal{A}}(\mathcal{D})\in\mathcal{E}\right]roman_Pr [ over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_A end_ARG ( caligraphic_D ) ∈ caligraphic_E ] ≤Pr⁡[𝒜⁢(𝒟)∈ℰ]+δ′absentPr𝒜𝒟ℰsuperscript𝛿′\displaystyle\leq\Pr\left[\mathcal{A}(\mathcal{D})\in\mathcal{E}\right]+\delta% ^{\prime}≤ roman_Pr [ caligraphic_A ( caligraphic_D ) ∈ caligraphic_E ] + italic_δ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT
≤exp⁡(ϵ)⁢Pr⁡[𝒜⁢(𝒟′)∈ℰ]+δ+δ′absentitalic-ϵPr𝒜superscript𝒟′ℰ𝛿superscript𝛿′\displaystyle\leq\exp\left(\epsilon\right)\Pr\left[\mathcal{A}(\mathcal{D}^{% \prime})\in\mathcal{E}\right]+\delta+\delta^{\prime}≤ roman_exp ( italic_ϵ ) roman_Pr [ caligraphic_A ( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ∈ caligraphic_E ] + italic_δ + italic_δ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT
≤exp⁡(ϵ)⁢Pr⁡[𝒜¯⁢(𝒟′)∈ℰ]+δ+4⁢δ′.absentitalic-ϵPr¯𝒜superscript𝒟′ℰ𝛿4superscript𝛿′\displaystyle\leq\exp\left(\epsilon\right)\Pr\left[\overline{\mathcal{A}}(% \mathcal{D}^{\prime})\in\mathcal{E}\right]+\delta+4\delta^{\prime}.≤ roman_exp ( italic_ϵ ) roman_Pr [ over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_A end_ARG ( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ∈ caligraphic_E ] + italic_δ + 4 italic_δ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

The first and last lines used the assumption between 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A and 𝒜¯¯𝒜\overline{\mathcal{A}}over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_A end_ARG, and the second line used that 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A is DP. ∎

We next recall the following well-known result on detecting the first large element in a stream.

Lemma 2 (Theorems 3.23, 3.24, [DR14]).

𝖠𝖻𝗈𝗏𝖾𝖳𝗁𝗋𝖾𝗌𝗁𝗈𝗅𝖽𝖠𝖻𝗈𝗏𝖾𝖳𝗁𝗋𝖾𝗌𝗁𝗈𝗅𝖽\mathsf{AboveThreshold}sansserif_AboveThreshold is (ϵ,0)italic-ϵ0(\epsilon,0)( italic_ϵ , 0 )-DP. Moreover, for γ∈(0,1)𝛾01\gamma\in(0,1)italic_γ ∈ ( 0 , 1 ), let α=8⁢Δ⁢log⁡(2⁢Tγ)ϵ𝛼8Δ2𝑇𝛾italic-ϵ\alpha=\frac{8\Delta\log(\frac{2T}{\gamma})}{\epsilon}italic_α = divide start_ARG 8 roman_Δ roman_log ( divide start_ARG 2 italic_T end_ARG start_ARG italic_γ end_ARG ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_ϵ end_ARG and 𝒟∈𝒳n𝒟superscript𝒳𝑛\mathcal{D}\in\mathcal{X}^{n}caligraphic_D ∈ caligraphic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. 𝖠𝖻𝗈𝗏𝖾𝖳𝗁𝗋𝖾𝗌𝗁𝗈𝗅𝖽𝖠𝖻𝗈𝗏𝖾𝖳𝗁𝗋𝖾𝗌𝗁𝗈𝗅𝖽\mathsf{AboveThreshold}sansserif_AboveThreshold halts at time k∈[T+1]𝑘delimited-[]𝑇1k\in[T+1]italic_k ∈ [ italic_T + 1 ] such that with probability ≥1−γabsent1𝛾\geq 1-\gamma≥ 1 - italic_γ:

  • •

    at=⊥subscript𝑎𝑡bottoma_{t}=\botitalic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ⊥ and qt⁢(𝒟)≤τ+αsubscript𝑞𝑡𝒟𝜏𝛼q_{t}(\mathcal{D})\leq\tau+\alphaitalic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_D ) ≤ italic_τ + italic_α for all t<k𝑡𝑘t<kitalic_t < italic_k.

  • •

    ak=⊤subscript𝑎𝑘topa_{k}=\topitalic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ⊤ and qk⁢(𝒟)≥τ−αsubscript𝑞𝑘𝒟𝜏𝛼q_{k}(\mathcal{D})\geq\tau-\alphaitalic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_D ) ≥ italic_τ - italic_α or k=T+1𝑘𝑇1k=T+1italic_k = italic_T + 1.

Finally, our developments in Section 4 use the notions of Rényi DP (RDP) and central DP (CDP). We provide a self-contained summary of the definitions and properties satisfied by RDP and CDP here, but refer the reader to [BS16, Mir17] for a more detailed overview.

Definition 2 (RDP and CDP).

Let α≥1𝛼1\alpha\geq 1italic_α ≥ 1, ρ≥0𝜌0\rho\geq 0italic_ρ ≥ 0. We say that a randomized algorithm 𝒜:𝒳n→Ω:𝒜→superscript𝒳𝑛Ω\mathcal{A}:\mathcal{X}^{n}\to\Omegacaligraphic_A : caligraphic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → roman_Ω satisfies (α,ρ)𝛼𝜌(\alpha,\rho)( italic_α , italic_ρ )-Rényi differential privacy (or, is (α,ρ)𝛼𝜌(\alpha,\rho)( italic_α , italic_ρ )-RDP) if for all neighboring datasets 𝒟,𝒟′∈𝒳n𝒟superscript𝒟′superscript𝒳𝑛\mathcal{D},\mathcal{D}^{\prime}\in\mathcal{X}^{n}caligraphic_D , caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT,

Dα⁢(𝒜⁢(𝒟)∥𝒜⁢(𝒟′))≤α⁢ρ.subscript𝐷𝛼conditional𝒜𝒟𝒜superscript𝒟′𝛼𝜌D_{\alpha}(\mathcal{A}(\mathcal{D})\|\mathcal{A}(\mathcal{D}^{\prime}))\leq% \alpha\rho.italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_α end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_A ( caligraphic_D ) ∥ caligraphic_A ( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) ≤ italic_α italic_ρ .

If this holds for all α≥1𝛼1\alpha\geq 1italic_α ≥ 1, we say 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A satisfies ρ𝜌\rhoitalic_ρ-central differential privacy (or, is ρ𝜌\rhoitalic_ρ-CDP).

Fact 4 ([Mir17]).

RDP and CDP satisfy the following properties.

  1. 1.

    (Composition): If 𝒜1:𝒳n→Ω1:subscript𝒜1→superscript𝒳𝑛subscriptΩ1\mathcal{A}_{1}:\mathcal{X}^{n}\to\Omega_{1}caligraphic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : caligraphic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → roman_Ω start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is (α,ρ1)𝛼subscript𝜌1(\alpha,\rho_{1})( italic_α , italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )-RDP and 𝒜2:𝒳n×Ω1→Ω2:subscript𝒜2→superscript𝒳𝑛subscriptΩ1subscriptΩ2\mathcal{A}_{2}:\mathcal{X}^{n}\times\Omega_{1}\to\Omega_{2}caligraphic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : caligraphic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT × roman_Ω start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT → roman_Ω start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is (α,ρ2)𝛼subscript𝜌2(\alpha,\rho_{2})( italic_α , italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) for any fixed choice of input from Ω1subscriptΩ1\Omega_{1}roman_Ω start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the composition of 𝒜2subscript𝒜2\mathcal{A}_{2}caligraphic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and 𝒜1subscript𝒜1\mathcal{A}_{1}caligraphic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is (α,ρ1+ρ2)𝛼subscript𝜌1subscript𝜌2(\alpha,\rho_{1}+\rho_{2})( italic_α , italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )-RDP.

  2. 2.

    (RDP to DP): If 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A is (α,ρ)𝛼𝜌(\alpha,\rho)( italic_α , italic_ρ )-RDP, it is also (α⁢ρ+1α−1⁢log⁡1δ,δ)𝛼𝜌1𝛼11𝛿𝛿(\alpha\rho+\frac{1}{\alpha-1}\log\frac{1}{\delta},\delta)( italic_α italic_ρ + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_α - 1 end_ARG roman_log divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG , italic_δ )-DP for all δ∈(0,1)𝛿01\delta\in(0,1)italic_δ ∈ ( 0 , 1 ).

  3. 3.

    (Gaussian mechanism): Let 𝐯:𝒳n→ℝk:𝐯→superscript𝒳𝑛superscriptℝ𝑘\mathbf{v}:\mathcal{X}^{n}\to\mathbb{R}^{k}bold_v : caligraphic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → roman_ℝ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT have sensitivity ΔΔ\Deltaroman_Δ. Then for any σ>0𝜎0\sigma>0italic_σ > 0, drawing a sample from 𝒩⁢(𝐯⁢(𝒟),σ2⁢𝐈k)𝒩𝐯𝒟superscript𝜎2subscript𝐈𝑘\mathcal{N}(\mathbf{v}(\mathcal{D}),\sigma^{2}\mathbf{I}_{k})caligraphic_N ( bold_v ( caligraphic_D ) , italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is Δ22⁢σ2superscriptΔ22superscript𝜎2\frac{\Delta^{2}}{2\sigma^{2}}divide start_ARG roman_Δ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG-CDP.

2.3 Geometric median

Throughout the rest of the paper, for a parameter R>0𝑅0R>0italic_R > 0, we fix a dataset 𝒟:={𝐱i}i∈[n]⊂𝔹d⁢(R)assign𝒟subscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖𝑖delimited-[]𝑛superscript𝔹𝑑𝑅\mathcal{D}:=\{\mathbf{x}_{i}\}_{i\in[n]}\subset\mathbb{B}^{d}(R)caligraphic_D := { bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⊂ roman_𝔹 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_R ), i.e., with domain 𝒳:=𝔹d⁢(R)assign𝒳superscript𝔹𝑑𝑅\mathcal{X}:=\mathbb{B}^{d}(R)caligraphic_X := roman_𝔹 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_R ). Our goal is to approximate the geometric median of 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D, i.e.,

𝐱⋆⁢(𝒟):=arg⁡min𝐱∈ℝd⁡f𝒟⁢(𝐱), where ⁢f𝒟⁢(𝐱):=1n⁢∑i∈[n]∥𝐱−𝐱i∥formulae-sequenceassignsubscript𝐱⋆𝒟subscript𝐱superscriptℝ𝑑subscript𝑓𝒟𝐱assign where subscript𝑓𝒟𝐱1𝑛subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛delimited-∥∥𝐱subscript𝐱𝑖\displaystyle\mathbf{x}_{\star}(\mathcal{D}):=\arg\min_{\mathbf{x}\in\mathbb{R% }^{d}}f_{\mathcal{D}}(\mathbf{x}),\text{ where }f_{\mathcal{D}}(\mathbf{x}):=% \frac{1}{n}\sum_{i\in[n]}\left\lVert\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}_{i}\right\rVertbold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_D ) := roman_arg roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∈ roman_ℝ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) , where italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) := divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ bold_x - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ (3)

is the average Euclidean distance to the dataset. Following e.g., [CLM+16, HSU24], we also define the quantile radii associated with our dataset 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D centered at 𝐱¯∈ℝd¯𝐱superscriptℝ𝑑\bar{\mathbf{x}}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}over¯ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG ∈ roman_ℝ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT by

r(τ)⁢(𝒟;𝐱¯):=arg⁡minr≥0⁡{∑i∈[n]𝕀∥𝐱i−𝐱¯∥≤r≥τ⁢n}, for all ⁢τ∈[0,1].formulae-sequenceassignsuperscript𝑟𝜏𝒟¯𝐱subscript𝑟0subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛subscript𝕀delimited-∥∥subscript𝐱𝑖¯𝐱𝑟𝜏𝑛 for all 𝜏01r^{(\tau)}(\mathcal{D};\bar{\mathbf{x}}):=\arg\min_{r\geq 0}\left\{\sum_{i\in[% n]}\mathbb{I}_{\left\lVert\mathbf{x}_{i}-\bar{\mathbf{x}}\right\rVert\leq r}% \geq\tau n\right\},\text{ for all }\tau\in[0,1].italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_τ ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( caligraphic_D ; over¯ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG ) := roman_arg roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r ≥ 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT { ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_𝕀 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - over¯ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG ∥ ≤ italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ italic_τ italic_n } , for all italic_τ ∈ [ 0 , 1 ] . (4)

In other words, r(τ)⁢(𝒟;𝐱¯)superscript𝑟𝜏𝒟¯𝐱r^{(\tau)}(\mathcal{D};\bar{\mathbf{x}})italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_τ ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( caligraphic_D ; over¯ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG ) is the smallest radius r≥0𝑟0r\geq 0italic_r ≥ 0 such that 𝔹d⁢(𝐱¯,r)superscript𝔹𝑑¯𝐱𝑟\mathbb{B}^{d}(\bar{\mathbf{x}},r)roman_𝔹 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( over¯ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG , italic_r ) contains at least a τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ fraction of the points in 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D. When 𝐱¯¯𝐱\bar{\mathbf{x}}over¯ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG is unspecified, we always assume by default that 𝐱¯=𝐱⋆⁢(𝒟)¯𝐱subscript𝐱⋆𝒟\bar{\mathbf{x}}=\mathbf{x}_{\star}(\mathcal{D})over¯ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG = bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_D ).

In our utility analysis we will often suppress the dependence on 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D in 𝐱⋆,r(τ)subscript𝐱⋆superscript𝑟𝜏\mathbf{x}_{\star},r^{(\tau)}bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_τ ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, etc., as the dataset of interest will not change. In the privacy analysis, we specify the dependence of these functions on the dataset explicitly when comparing algorithms run on neighboring datasets.

Finally, we include two helper results from prior work that are frequently used throughout.

Lemma 3.

Let 𝒟:={𝐱i}i∈[n]⊂ℝdassign𝒟subscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖𝑖delimited-[]𝑛superscriptℝ𝑑\mathcal{D}:=\{\mathbf{x}_{i}\}_{i\in[n]}\subset\mathbb{R}^{d}caligraphic_D := { bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⊂ roman_ℝ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Then, f𝒟⁢(𝐱⋆)≥(1−τ)⁢r(τ)subscript𝑓𝒟subscript𝐱⋆1𝜏superscript𝑟𝜏f_{\mathcal{D}}\left(\mathbf{x}_{\star}\right)\geq(1-\tau)r^{(\tau)}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ≥ ( 1 - italic_τ ) italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_τ ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for all τ∈[0,1]𝜏01\tau\in[0,1]italic_τ ∈ [ 0 , 1 ].

Proof.

This is immediate from the definition of f𝒟subscript𝑓𝒟f_{\mathcal{D}}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and nonnegativity of each summand ∥⋅−𝐱i∥\left\lVert\cdot-\mathbf{x}_{i}\right\rVert∥ ⋅ - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥. ∎

Lemma 4 (Lemma 24, [CLM+16]).

Let 𝒟:={𝐱i}i∈[n]⊂ℝdassign𝒟subscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖𝑖delimited-[]𝑛superscriptℝ𝑑\mathcal{D}:=\{\mathbf{x}_{i}\}_{i\in[n]}\subset\mathbb{R}^{d}caligraphic_D := { bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⊂ roman_ℝ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and let S⊆[n]𝑆delimited-[]𝑛S\subseteq[n]italic_S ⊆ [ italic_n ] have |S|<n2𝑆𝑛2|S|<\frac{n}{2}| italic_S | < divide start_ARG italic_n end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG. Then,

∥𝐱⋆−𝐱∥≤(2⁢n−2⁢|S|n−2⁢|S|)⁢maxi∉S⁡‖𝐱i−𝐱‖, for all ⁢𝐱∈ℝd.formulae-sequencedelimited-∥∥subscript𝐱⋆𝐱2𝑛2𝑆𝑛2𝑆subscript𝑖𝑆normsubscript𝐱𝑖𝐱 for all 𝐱superscriptℝ𝑑\left\lVert\mathbf{x}_{\star}-\mathbf{x}\right\rVert\leq\left(\frac{2n-2|S|}{n% -2|S|}\right)\max_{i\notin S}\|\mathbf{x}_{i}-\mathbf{x}\|,\text{ for all }% \mathbf{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}.∥ bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_x ∥ ≤ ( divide start_ARG 2 italic_n - 2 | italic_S | end_ARG start_ARG italic_n - 2 | italic_S | end_ARG ) roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∉ italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_x ∥ , for all bold_x ∈ roman_ℝ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

3 Constant-Factor Approximation

In this section, we give our first main result: a fast algorithm for computing a constant-factor approximation to the geometric median. Our approach is to speed up several of the steps in the initial two phases of the [HSU24] algorithm via subsampling and techniques inspired by the FriendlyCore framework of [TCK+22]. Specifically, in Section 3.1, we first show how Algorithm 1 can be sped up using subsampled scores, to estimate quantile radii up to constant factors in nearly-linear time, improving Section 2.1 of [HSU24]. In Section 3.2, we then adapt a weighted variant of FriendlyCore to give a simple algorithm for approximate centerpoint computation, improving Section 2.2 of [HSU24] for large aspect ratios.

3.1 Radius estimation

In this section, we present and analyze our radius estimation algorithm.

Algorithm 2 is clearly an instance of Algorithm 1 with Δ=3Δ3\Delta=3roman_Δ = 3, where the queries are given on Line 11. However, one subtlety is that the queries in Algorithm 2 have random sensitivities depending on the subsampled sets on Line 8. Nonetheless, we show that Chernoff bounds control this sensitivity with high probability, which yields privacy upon applying Lemma 2.

Lemma 5.

Algorithm 2 is (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)( italic_ϵ , italic_δ )-DP.

Proof.

Fix neighboring datasets 𝒟,𝒟′∈𝔹d⁢(R)n𝒟superscript𝒟′superscript𝔹𝑑superscript𝑅𝑛\mathcal{D},\mathcal{D}^{\prime}\in\mathbb{B}^{d}(R)^{n}caligraphic_D , caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ roman_𝔹 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_R ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and assume without loss that they differ in the nthsuperscript𝑛thn^{\text{th}}italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT th end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT entry. Observe that 𝖥𝖺𝗌𝗍𝖱𝖺𝖽𝗂𝗎𝗌𝖥𝖺𝗌𝗍𝖱𝖺𝖽𝗂𝗎𝗌\mathsf{FastRadius}sansserif_FastRadius (independently) uses randomness in two places: the random subsets in Line 8, and the Laplace noise added as in the original 𝖠𝖻𝗈𝗏𝖾𝖳𝗁𝗋𝖾𝗌𝗁𝗈𝗅𝖽𝖠𝖻𝗈𝗏𝖾𝖳𝗁𝗋𝖾𝗌𝗁𝗈𝗅𝖽\mathsf{AboveThreshold}sansserif_AboveThreshold algorithm in Lines 4 and 12.

We next claim that in any iteration t∈[T]𝑡delimited-[]𝑇t\in[T]italic_t ∈ [ italic_T ], as long as the number of copies of the index n𝑛nitalic_n occurring in ⋃i∈[n−1]St(i)subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛1superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑡𝑖\bigcup_{i\in[n-1]}S_{t}^{(i)}⋃ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_n - 1 ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_i ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is at most 2⁢k2𝑘2k2 italic_k, then the sensitivity of the query qtsubscript𝑞𝑡q_{t}italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is at most 3333. To see this, denoting by qt,qt′subscript𝑞𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑡′q_{t},q_{t}^{\prime}italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT the random queries when Algorithm 2 is run on 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D, 𝒟′superscript𝒟′\mathcal{D}^{\prime}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT respectively, and similarly defining {Nt(i),(Nt(i))′}i∈[n]subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑁𝑡𝑖superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑁𝑡𝑖′𝑖delimited-[]𝑛\{N_{t}^{(i)},(N_{t}^{(i)})^{\prime}\}_{i\in[n]}{ italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_i ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , ( italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_i ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we observe that the sensitivity is controlled as follows:

qt−qt′subscript𝑞𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝑞′𝑡\displaystyle q_{t}-q^{\prime}_{t}italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤1n⁢∑i∈[n−1](Nt(i)−(Nt(i))′)+nnabsent1𝑛subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛1superscriptsubscript𝑁𝑡𝑖superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑁𝑡𝑖′𝑛𝑛\displaystyle\leq\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i\in[n-1]}\left(N_{t}^{(i)}-\left(N_{t}^{(i)% }\right)^{\prime}\right)+\frac{n}{n}≤ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_n - 1 ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_i ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - ( italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_i ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) + divide start_ARG italic_n end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG
≤1n⋅nk⋅(number of copies of ⁢n⁢ occurring in ⁢⋃i∈[n−1]St(i))+1≤3.absent⋅1𝑛𝑛𝑘number of copies of 𝑛 occurring in subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛1superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑡𝑖13\displaystyle\leq\frac{1}{n}\cdot\frac{n}{k}\cdot\left(\text{number of copies % of }n\text{ occurring in }\bigcup_{i\in[n-1]}S_{t}^{(i)}\right)+1\leq 3.≤ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG ⋅ divide start_ARG italic_n end_ARG start_ARG italic_k end_ARG ⋅ ( number of copies of italic_n occurring in ⋃ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_n - 1 ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_i ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) + 1 ≤ 3 .

The first line holds because the nthsuperscript𝑛thn^{\text{th}}italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT th end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (neighboring) point has Nt(n)≤nsuperscriptsubscript𝑁𝑡𝑛𝑛N_{t}^{(n)}\leq nitalic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≤ italic_n and (Nt(n))′≥0superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑁𝑡𝑛′0(N_{t}^{(n)})^{\prime}\geq 0( italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≥ 0; the second is because every 𝕀∥𝐱i−𝐱j∥≤rtsubscript𝕀delimited-∥∥subscript𝐱𝑖subscript𝐱𝑗subscript𝑟𝑡\mathbb{I}_{\left\lVert\mathbf{x}_{i}-\mathbf{x}_{j}\right\rVert\leq r_{t}}roman_𝕀 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ ≤ italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT used in the computation of Nt(i)superscriptsubscript𝑁𝑡𝑖N_{t}^{(i)}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_i ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is coupled except when j=n𝑗𝑛j=nitalic_j = italic_n is sampled.

Now, let 𝒜¯¯𝒜\overline{\mathcal{A}}over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_A end_ARG denote Algorithm 2, and let 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A denote a variant that conditions on the randomly-sampled ⋃i∈[n−1]St(i)subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛1superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑡𝑖\bigcup_{i\in[n-1]}S_{t}^{(i)}⋃ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_n - 1 ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_i ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT containing at most 2⁢k2𝑘2k2 italic_k copies of the index n𝑛nitalic_n, in all encountered iterations t∈[T]𝑡delimited-[]𝑇t\in[T]italic_t ∈ [ italic_T ]. By using Fact 1 (with μ←k⋅n−1n←𝜇⋅𝑘𝑛1𝑛\mu\leftarrow k\cdot\frac{n-1}{n}italic_μ ← italic_k ⋅ divide start_ARG italic_n - 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG, ϵ←1←italic-ϵ1\epsilon\leftarrow 1italic_ϵ ← 1), due to our choice of k𝑘kitalic_k, ⋃i∈[n−1]St(i)subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛1superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑡𝑖\bigcup_{i\in[n-1]}S_{t}^{(i)}⋃ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_n - 1 ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_i ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT contains at most 2⁢k2𝑘2k2 italic_k copies of n𝑛nitalic_n except with probability δ4⁢T𝛿4𝑇\frac{\delta}{4T}divide start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG start_ARG 4 italic_T end_ARG, so by a union bound, the total variation distance between 𝒜¯¯𝒜\overline{\mathcal{A}}over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_A end_ARG and 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A is at most δ4𝛿4\frac{\delta}{4}divide start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG. Moreover, 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A is (ϵ,0)italic-ϵ0(\epsilon,0)( italic_ϵ , 0 )-DP by using Lemma 2. Thus, 𝒜¯¯𝒜\overline{\mathcal{A}}over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_A end_ARG is (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)( italic_ϵ , italic_δ )-DP using Lemma 1. ∎

We are now ready to prove a utility and runtime guarantee on Algorithm 2.

Lemma 6.

Algorithm 2 runs in time O⁢(n⁢d⁢log⁡(Rr)⁢log⁡(log⁡(Rr)⁢1δ))𝑂𝑛𝑑𝑅𝑟𝑅𝑟1𝛿O(nd\log(\frac{R}{r})\log(\log(\frac{R}{r})\frac{1}{\delta}))italic_O ( italic_n italic_d roman_log ( divide start_ARG italic_R end_ARG start_ARG italic_r end_ARG ) roman_log ( roman_log ( divide start_ARG italic_R end_ARG start_ARG italic_r end_ARG ) divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG ) ). Moreover, if r≤4⁢r(0.9)𝑟4superscript𝑟0.9r\leq 4r^{(0.9)}italic_r ≤ 4 italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0.9 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and n≥2400ϵ⁢log⁡(4⁢Tδ)𝑛2400italic-ϵ4𝑇𝛿n\geq\frac{2400}{\epsilon}\log(\frac{4T}{\delta})italic_n ≥ divide start_ARG 2400 end_ARG start_ARG italic_ϵ end_ARG roman_log ( divide start_ARG 4 italic_T end_ARG start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG ), with probability ≥1−δabsent1𝛿\geq 1-\delta≥ 1 - italic_δ, Algorithm 2 outputs r^^𝑟\hat{r}over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG satisfying 14⁢r(0.75)≤r^≤4⁢r(0.9)14superscript𝑟0.75^𝑟4superscript𝑟0.9\frac{1}{4}r^{(0.75)}\leq\hat{r}\leq 4r^{(0.9)}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0.75 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≤ over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG ≤ 4 italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0.9 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Proof.

The first claim is immediate. To see the second, for all t∈[T]𝑡delimited-[]𝑇t\in[T]italic_t ∈ [ italic_T ] denote the “ideal” query by:

qt⋆:=1n⁢∑i∈[n]∑j∈[n]𝕀∥𝐱i−𝐱j∥≤rt,assignsubscriptsuperscript𝑞⋆𝑡1𝑛subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛subscript𝑗delimited-[]𝑛subscript𝕀delimited-∥∥subscript𝐱𝑖subscript𝐱𝑗subscript𝑟𝑡q^{\star}_{t}:=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i\in[n]}\sum_{j\in[n]}\mathbb{I}_{\left\lVert% \mathbf{x}_{i}-\mathbf{x}_{j}\right\rVert\leq r_{t}},italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j ∈ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_𝕀 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ ≤ italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ,

and recall 𝔼⁢qt=qt⋆𝔼subscript𝑞𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝑞⋆𝑡\mathbb{E}q_{t}=q^{\star}_{t}roman_𝔼 italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Our first claim is that with probability ≥1−δ2absent1𝛿2\geq 1-\frac{\delta}{2}≥ 1 - divide start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG, the following guarantees hold for all iterations t∈[T]𝑡delimited-[]𝑇t\in[T]italic_t ∈ [ italic_T ] that Algorithm 2 completes:

qt⋆>0.8⁢n⟹qt>0.79⁢n, and ⁢qt⋆<0.75⁢n⟹qt<0.76⁢n.formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscript𝑞⋆𝑡0.8𝑛subscript𝑞𝑡0.79𝑛 and subscriptsuperscript𝑞⋆𝑡0.75𝑛subscript𝑞𝑡0.76𝑛q^{\star}_{t}>0.8n\implies q_{t}>0.79n,\text{ and }q^{\star}_{t}<0.75n\implies q% _{t}<0.76n.italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0.8 italic_n ⟹ italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0.79 italic_n , and italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < 0.75 italic_n ⟹ italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < 0.76 italic_n . (5)

To see the first part of (5), we can view n⁢qt𝑛subscript𝑞𝑡nq_{t}italic_n italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as a random sum of Bernoulli variables with mean n⁢qt⋆>0.8⁢n2≥20000⁢log⁡(δ4⁢T)𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑡⋆0.8superscript𝑛220000𝛿4𝑇nq_{t}^{\star}>0.8n^{2}\geq 20000\log(\frac{\delta}{4T})italic_n italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT > 0.8 italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≥ 20000 roman_log ( divide start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG start_ARG 4 italic_T end_ARG ), so Fact 1 with ϵ←180←italic-ϵ180\epsilon\leftarrow\frac{1}{80}italic_ϵ ← divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 80 end_ARG yields the claim in iteration t𝑡titalic_t with probability ≥1−δ2⁢Tabsent1𝛿2𝑇\geq 1-\frac{\delta}{2T}≥ 1 - divide start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_T end_ARG. Similarly, the second part of (5) follows by using Fact 1 with μ<0.7⁢n2𝜇0.7superscript𝑛2\mu<0.7n^{2}italic_μ < 0.7 italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and (1+ϵ)⁢μ←0.71⁢n2←1italic-ϵ𝜇0.71superscript𝑛2(1+\epsilon)\mu\leftarrow 0.71n^{2}( 1 + italic_ϵ ) italic_μ ← 0.71 italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, because

exp⁡(−ϵ2⁢μ2+ϵ)≤exp⁡(−ϵ2⁢μ151⁢ϵ)=exp⁡(−ϵ⁢μ151)≤exp⁡(−n215100)≤δ2⁢Tsuperscriptitalic-ϵ2𝜇2italic-ϵsuperscriptitalic-ϵ2𝜇151italic-ϵitalic-ϵ𝜇151superscript𝑛215100𝛿2𝑇\exp\left(-\frac{\epsilon^{2}\mu}{2+\epsilon}\right)\leq\exp\left(-\frac{% \epsilon^{2}\mu}{151\epsilon}\right)=\exp\left(-\frac{\epsilon\mu}{151}\right)% \leq\exp\left(-\frac{n^{2}}{15100}\right)\leq\frac{\delta}{2T}roman_exp ( - divide start_ARG italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_μ end_ARG start_ARG 2 + italic_ϵ end_ARG ) ≤ roman_exp ( - divide start_ARG italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_μ end_ARG start_ARG 151 italic_ϵ end_ARG ) = roman_exp ( - divide start_ARG italic_ϵ italic_μ end_ARG start_ARG 151 end_ARG ) ≤ roman_exp ( - divide start_ARG italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 15100 end_ARG ) ≤ divide start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_T end_ARG (6)

for the relevant range of n𝑛nitalic_n and ϵ≥175italic-ϵ175\epsilon\geq\frac{1}{75}italic_ϵ ≥ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 75 end_ARG, ϵ⁢μ≥n2100italic-ϵ𝜇superscript𝑛2100\epsilon\mu\geq\frac{n^{2}}{100}italic_ϵ italic_μ ≥ divide start_ARG italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 100 end_ARG. We thus obtain (5) after a union bound over all t∈[T]𝑡delimited-[]𝑇t\in[T]italic_t ∈ [ italic_T ].

Now, suppose that t∈[T]𝑡delimited-[]𝑇t\in[T]italic_t ∈ [ italic_T ] is the first index where qt+νt≥τ^subscript𝑞𝑡subscript𝜈𝑡^𝜏q_{t}+\nu_{t}\geq\hat{\tau}italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_ν start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ over^ start_ARG italic_τ end_ARG, so that r^=rt^𝑟subscript𝑟𝑡\hat{r}=r_{t}over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG = italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and 12⁢r^=rt−112^𝑟subscript𝑟𝑡1\frac{1}{2}\hat{r}=r_{t-1}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG = italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where we let r0:=r2assignsubscript𝑟0𝑟2r_{0}:=\frac{r}{2}italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := divide start_ARG italic_r end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG. If no such query passes, then we set t=T+1𝑡𝑇1t=T+1italic_t = italic_T + 1 by default. Then by the utility guarantees of Lemma 6, we have that with probability ≥1−δ2absent1𝛿2\geq 1-\frac{\delta}{2}≥ 1 - divide start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG,

qt≥0.76⁢n,qt−1≤0.79⁢n,formulae-sequencesubscript𝑞𝑡0.76𝑛subscript𝑞𝑡10.79𝑛\displaystyle q_{t}\geq 0.76n,\;q_{t-1}\leq 0.79n,italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ 0.76 italic_n , italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ 0.79 italic_n ,

since n100≥α=24ϵ⁢log⁡(4⁢Tδ)𝑛100𝛼24italic-ϵ4𝑇𝛿\frac{n}{100}\geq\alpha=\frac{24}{\epsilon}\log(\frac{4T}{\delta})divide start_ARG italic_n end_ARG start_ARG 100 end_ARG ≥ italic_α = divide start_ARG 24 end_ARG start_ARG italic_ϵ end_ARG roman_log ( divide start_ARG 4 italic_T end_ARG start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG ) . By taking the contrapositive of (5), we can conclude that with probability ≥1−δabsent1𝛿\geq 1-\delta≥ 1 - italic_δ, we have qt⋆≥0.75⁢nsubscriptsuperscript𝑞⋆𝑡0.75𝑛q^{\star}_{t}\geq 0.75nitalic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ 0.75 italic_n and qt−1⋆≤0.8⁢nsubscriptsuperscript𝑞⋆𝑡10.8𝑛q^{\star}_{t-1}\leq 0.8nitalic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ 0.8 italic_n. Condition on this event for the rest of the proof.

Because qt⋆≥0.75⁢nsuperscriptsubscript𝑞𝑡⋆0.75𝑛q_{t}^{\star}\geq 0.75nitalic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≥ 0.75 italic_n, there is clearly some 𝐱i∈𝒟subscript𝐱𝑖𝒟\mathbf{x}_{i}\in\mathcal{D}bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_D such that |𝒟∩𝔹d⁢(𝐱i,r^)|≥0.75⁢n𝒟superscript𝔹𝑑subscript𝐱𝑖^𝑟0.75𝑛|\mathcal{D}\cap\mathbb{B}^{d}(\mathbf{x}_{i},\hat{r})|\geq 0.75n| caligraphic_D ∩ roman_𝔹 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG ) | ≥ 0.75 italic_n, as this is the average number of dataset elements in a radius-r^^𝑟\hat{r}over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG ball centered at a random 𝐱∈𝒟𝐱𝒟\mathbf{x}\in\mathcal{D}bold_x ∈ caligraphic_D. Now applying Lemma 4 with S𝑆Sitalic_S set to the indices of 𝒟∖𝔹d⁢(𝐱i,r^)𝒟superscript𝔹𝑑subscript𝐱𝑖^𝑟\mathcal{D}\setminus\mathbb{B}^{d}(\mathbf{x}_{i},\hat{r})caligraphic_D ∖ roman_𝔹 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG ), so that |S|≤0.25⁢n𝑆0.25𝑛|S|\leq 0.25n| italic_S | ≤ 0.25 italic_n, gives
