∥𝐱⋆−𝐱i∥≤3⁢r^⟹∥𝐱⋆−𝐱j∥≤4⁢r^⁢ for all ⁢𝐱j∈𝒟∩𝔹d⁢(𝐱i,r^).delimited-∥∥subscript𝐱⋆subscript𝐱𝑖3^𝑟delimited-∥∥subscript𝐱⋆subscript𝐱𝑗4^𝑟 for all subscript𝐱𝑗𝒟superscript𝔹𝑑subscript𝐱𝑖^𝑟\left\lVert\mathbf{x}_{\star}-\mathbf{x}_{i}\right\rVert\leq 3\hat{r}\implies% \left\lVert\mathbf{x}_{\star}-\mathbf{x}_{j}\right\rVert\leq 4\hat{r}\text{ % for all }\mathbf{x}_{j}\in\mathcal{D}\cap\mathbb{B}^{d}(\mathbf{x}_{i},\hat{r}).∥ bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ ≤ 3 over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG ⟹ ∥ bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ ≤ 4 over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG for all bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_D ∩ roman_𝔹 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG ) .

This implies 4⁢r^≥r(0.75)4^𝑟superscript𝑟0.754\hat{r}\geq r^{(0.75)}4 over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG ≥ italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0.75 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as claimed. Further, because qt−1⋆≤0.8⁢nsuperscriptsubscript𝑞𝑡1⋆0.8𝑛q_{t-1}^{\star}\leq 0.8nitalic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≤ 0.8 italic_n, we claim r^2>2⁢r(0.9)^𝑟22superscript𝑟0.9\frac{\hat{r}}{2}>2r^{(0.9)}divide start_ARG over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG > 2 italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0.9 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT cannot hold. Assume for contradiction that this happened, and let S:=𝒟∩𝔹d⁢(𝐱⋆,r(0.9))assign𝑆𝒟superscript𝔹𝑑subscript𝐱⋆superscript𝑟0.9S:=\mathcal{D}\cap\mathbb{B}^{d}(\mathbf{x}_{\star},r^{(0.9)})italic_S := caligraphic_D ∩ roman_𝔹 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0.9 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). By the triangle inequality, for all of the 0.9⁢n0.9𝑛0.9n0.9 italic_n choices of 𝐱i∈Ssubscript𝐱𝑖𝑆\mathbf{x}_{i}\in Sbold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ italic_S, we have that

∑j∈[n]𝕀∥𝐱i−𝐱j∥≤r^2≥0.9⁢n,subscript𝑗delimited-[]𝑛subscript𝕀delimited-∥∥subscript𝐱𝑖subscript𝐱𝑗^𝑟20.9𝑛\sum_{j\in[n]}\mathbb{I}_{\left\lVert\mathbf{x}_{i}-\mathbf{x}_{j}\right\rVert% \leq\frac{\hat{r}}{2}}\geq 0.9n,∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j ∈ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_𝕀 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ ≤ divide start_ARG over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ 0.9 italic_n ,

which implies that qt−1⋆≥0.81⁢nsubscriptsuperscript𝑞⋆𝑡10.81𝑛q^{\star}_{t-1}\geq 0.81nitalic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ 0.81 italic_n, a contradiction. Thus, we obtain r^≤4⁢r(0.9)^𝑟4superscript𝑟0.9\hat{r}\leq 4r^{(0.9)}over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG ≤ 4 italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0.9 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as well.

We remark that all of this logic handles the case where 2≤t≤T2𝑡𝑇2\leq t\leq T2 ≤ italic_t ≤ italic_T is the iteration where Algorithm 2 returns. However, it is straightforward to check that the conclusion holds when t=1𝑡1t=1italic_t = 1 (i.e., r^=r^𝑟𝑟\hat{r}=rover^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG = italic_r) because we assumed r≤4⁢r(0.9)𝑟4superscript𝑟0.9r\leq 4r^{(0.9)}italic_r ≤ 4 italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0.9 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and the lower bound logic on r^^𝑟\hat{r}over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG is the same as before. Similarly, if r^=R^𝑟𝑅\hat{r}=Rover^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG = italic_R, then the upper bound logic on r^^𝑟\hat{r}over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG is the same as before, and 2⁢R≥r(1)≥r(0.75)≥24⁢r(0.75)2𝑅superscript𝑟1superscript𝑟0.7524superscript𝑟0.752R\geq r^{(1)}\geq r^{(0.75)}\geq\frac{2}{4}r^{(0.75)}2 italic_R ≥ italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≥ italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0.75 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≥ divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0.75 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is clear. ∎

In summary, Lemmas 5 and 6 show that we can privately estimate r^^𝑟\hat{r}over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG satisfying 14⁢r(0.75)≤r^≤4⁢r(0.9)14superscript𝑟0.75^𝑟4superscript𝑟0.9\frac{1}{4}r^{(0.75)}\leq\hat{r}\leq 4r^{(0.9)}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0.75 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≤ over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG ≤ 4 italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0.9 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in nearly-linear time. The upper bound implies (with Lemma 3) that r^=O⁢(f𝒟⁢(𝐱⋆))^𝑟𝑂subscript𝑓𝒟subscript𝐱⋆\hat{r}=O(f_{\mathcal{D}}(\mathbf{x}_{\star}))over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG = italic_O ( italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ); on the other hand, the lower bound will be critically used in our centerpoint estimation procedure in Section 3.2.

3.2 Centerpoint estimation

In this section, we combine the subsampling strategies used in Section 3.1 with a simplification of the FriendlyCore framework [TCK+22] to obtain a private estimate of an approximate centerpoint.

To briefly explain, Algorithm 3 outputs a noisy weighted average of the dataset. The weights {pi}i∈[n]subscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖𝑖delimited-[]𝑛\{p_{i}\}_{i\in[n]}{ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT linearly interpolate estimated scores fi∈[0.5⁢k,0.75⁢k]subscript𝑓𝑖0.5𝑘0.75𝑘f_{i}\in[0.5k,0.75k]italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ [ 0.5 italic_k , 0.75 italic_k ] into the range [0,1]01[0,1][ 0 , 1 ], sending fi≥0.75⁢ksubscript𝑓𝑖0.75𝑘f_{i}\geq 0.75kitalic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ 0.75 italic_k to 1111, and fi≤0.5⁢ksubscript𝑓𝑖0.5𝑘f_{i}\leq 0.5kitalic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ 0.5 italic_k to 00. We first make some basic observations about the points that contribute positively to the weighted combination 𝐱¯¯𝐱\bar{\mathbf{x}}over¯ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG, based on binomial concentration.

Lemma 7.

Assume that r^≥r(0.75)^𝑟superscript𝑟0.75\hat{r}\geq r^{(0.75)}over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG ≥ italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0.75 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in the context of Algorithm 3. With probability ≥1−δ18absent1𝛿18\geq 1-\frac{\delta}{18}≥ 1 - divide start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG start_ARG 18 end_ARG, every i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n]italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ] that is assigned pi>0subscript𝑝𝑖0p_{i}>0italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0 in Algorithm 3 satisfies ∥𝐱i−𝐱⋆∥≤3⁢r^delimited-∥∥subscript𝐱𝑖subscript𝐱⋆3^𝑟\left\lVert\mathbf{x}_{i}-\mathbf{x}_{\star}\right\rVert\leq 3\hat{r}∥ bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ ≤ 3 over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG, and Z≥0.6⁢n𝑍0.6𝑛Z\geq 0.6nitalic_Z ≥ 0.6 italic_n.

Proof.

Our proof is analogous to Lemma 6, where for all i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n]italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ] we define the “ideal score”

fi⋆:=kn⁢∑j∈[n]𝕀∥𝐱i−𝐱j∥≤2⁢r^,assignsubscriptsuperscript𝑓⋆𝑖𝑘𝑛subscript𝑗delimited-[]𝑛subscript𝕀delimited-∥∥subscript𝐱𝑖subscript𝐱𝑗2^𝑟f^{\star}_{i}:=\frac{k}{n}\sum_{j\in[n]}\mathbb{I}_{\left\lVert\mathbf{x}_{i}-% \mathbf{x}_{j}\right\rVert\leq 2\hat{r}},italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := divide start_ARG italic_k end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j ∈ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_𝕀 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ ≤ 2 over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ,

such that 𝔼⁢fi=fi⋆𝔼subscript𝑓𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑓⋆𝑖\mathbb{E}f_{i}=f^{\star}_{i}roman_𝔼 italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We first claim that with probability ≥1−δ18absent1𝛿18\geq 1-\frac{\delta}{18}≥ 1 - divide start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG start_ARG 18 end_ARG, the following hold for all i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n]italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ]:

fi⋆≥0.75⁢k⟹fi≥0.7⁢k, and ⁢fi⋆≤0.45⁢k⟹fi≤0.5⁢k.formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscript𝑓⋆𝑖0.75𝑘subscript𝑓𝑖0.7𝑘 and subscriptsuperscript𝑓⋆𝑖0.45𝑘subscript𝑓𝑖0.5𝑘f^{\star}_{i}\geq 0.75k\implies f_{i}\geq 0.7k,\text{ and }f^{\star}_{i}\leq 0% .45k\implies f_{i}\leq 0.5k.italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ 0.75 italic_k ⟹ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ 0.7 italic_k , and italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ 0.45 italic_k ⟹ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ 0.5 italic_k . (7)

The first claim above is immediate from our choice of k𝑘kitalic_k and Fact 1 (with failure probability ≤δ18⁢nabsent𝛿18𝑛\leq\frac{\delta}{18n}≤ divide start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG start_ARG 18 italic_n end_ARG for each i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n]italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ]); the second follows (with the same failure probability) similarly to (6), i.e.,

exp⁡(−ϵ2⁢μ2+ϵ)≤exp⁡(−ϵ⁢μ20)≤exp⁡(−k400)≤δ18⁢n,superscriptitalic-ϵ2𝜇2italic-ϵitalic-ϵ𝜇20𝑘400𝛿18𝑛\exp\left(-\frac{\epsilon^{2}\mu}{2+\epsilon}\right)\leq\exp\left(-\frac{% \epsilon\mu}{20}\right)\leq\exp\left(-\frac{k}{400}\right)\leq\frac{\delta}{18% n},roman_exp ( - divide start_ARG italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_μ end_ARG start_ARG 2 + italic_ϵ end_ARG ) ≤ roman_exp ( - divide start_ARG italic_ϵ italic_μ end_ARG start_ARG 20 end_ARG ) ≤ roman_exp ( - divide start_ARG italic_k end_ARG start_ARG 400 end_ARG ) ≤ divide start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG start_ARG 18 italic_n end_ARG ,

in our application, with ϵ≥19italic-ϵ19\epsilon\geq\frac{1}{9}italic_ϵ ≥ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 9 end_ARG and ϵ⁢μ≥k20italic-ϵ𝜇𝑘20\epsilon\mu\geq\frac{k}{20}italic_ϵ italic_μ ≥ divide start_ARG italic_k end_ARG start_ARG 20 end_ARG. Thus a union bound proves (7).

To obtain the first claim, observe that any i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n]italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ] with ∥𝐱i−𝐱⋆∥>3⁢r^delimited-∥∥subscript𝐱𝑖subscript𝐱⋆3^𝑟\left\lVert\mathbf{x}_{i}-\mathbf{x}_{\star}\right\rVert>3\hat{r}∥ bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ > 3 over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG must have that 𝔹⁢(𝐱i,2⁢r^)𝔹subscript𝐱𝑖2^𝑟\mathbb{B}(\mathbf{x}_{i},2\hat{r})roman_𝔹 ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , 2 over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG ) does not intersect 𝔹⁢(𝐱⋆,r^)𝔹subscript𝐱⋆^𝑟\mathbb{B}(\mathbf{x}_{\star},\hat{r})roman_𝔹 ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG ). However, 𝔹⁢(𝐱⋆,r^)𝔹subscript𝐱⋆^𝑟\mathbb{B}(\mathbf{x}_{\star},\hat{r})roman_𝔹 ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG ) contains 0.75⁢n0.75𝑛0.75n0.75 italic_n points in 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D by assumption, so fi⋆≤0.25⁢ksubscriptsuperscript𝑓⋆𝑖0.25𝑘f^{\star}_{i}\leq 0.25kitalic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ 0.25 italic_k and thus as long as the implication (7) holds, then pi=0subscript𝑝𝑖0p_{i}=0italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0 as desired. For the second claim, any 𝐱isubscript𝐱𝑖\mathbf{x}_{i}bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT satisfying ∥𝐱i−𝐱⋆∥≤r(0.75)delimited-∥∥subscript𝐱𝑖subscript𝐱⋆superscript𝑟0.75\left\lVert\mathbf{x}_{i}-\mathbf{x}_{\star}\right\rVert\leq r^{(0.75)}∥ bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ ≤ italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0.75 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT has |𝔹⁢(𝐱i,2⁢r^)∩𝒟|≥0.75⁢n𝔹subscript𝐱𝑖2^𝑟𝒟0.75𝑛|\mathbb{B}(\mathbf{x}_{i},2\hat{r})\cap\mathcal{D}|\geq 0.75n| roman_𝔹 ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , 2 over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG ) ∩ caligraphic_D | ≥ 0.75 italic_n, so that fi⋆≥0.7⁢ksubscriptsuperscript𝑓⋆𝑖0.7𝑘f^{\star}_{i}\geq 0.7kitalic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ 0.7 italic_k. Thus, every such 𝐱isubscript𝐱𝑖\mathbf{x}_{i}bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT has pi≥0.8subscript𝑝𝑖0.8p_{i}\geq 0.8italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ 0.8 as long as (7) holds, so the total contribution made by the ≥0.75⁢nabsent0.75𝑛\geq 0.75n≥ 0.75 italic_n such 𝐱isubscript𝐱𝑖\mathbf{x}_{i}bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to Z𝑍Zitalic_Z is at least 0.6⁢n0.6𝑛0.6n0.6 italic_n. ∎

We next observe that whenever the algorithm does not return on Line 10, all surviving points (i.e., with pi>0subscript𝑝𝑖0p_{i}>0italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0) must lie in a ball of diameter O⁢(r^)𝑂^𝑟O(\hat{r})italic_O ( over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG ), under a high-probability event over our subsampled scores. Importantly, this holds independently of any assumption on r^^𝑟\hat{r}over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG (e.g., we do not require r^≥r(0.75)^𝑟superscript𝑟0.75\hat{r}\geq r^{(0.75)}over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG ≥ italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0.75 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT).

Lemma 8.

Suppose that it is the case that in the context of Algorithm 3, we have

fi⋆≤0.45⁢k⟹fi≤0.5⁢k, and ⁢fi⋆≤0.55⁢k⟹fi≤0.6⁢k,formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscript𝑓⋆𝑖0.45𝑘subscript𝑓𝑖0.5𝑘 and subscriptsuperscript𝑓⋆𝑖0.55𝑘subscript𝑓𝑖0.6𝑘f^{\star}_{i}\leq 0.45k\implies f_{i}\leq 0.5k,\text{ and }f^{\star}_{i}\leq 0% .55k\implies f_{i}\leq 0.6k,italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ 0.45 italic_k ⟹ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ 0.5 italic_k , and italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ 0.55 italic_k ⟹ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ 0.6 italic_k , (8)

for all i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n]italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ]. If Z>0.55⁢n𝑍0.55𝑛Z>0.55nitalic_Z > 0.55 italic_n, there exists some 𝐱∈ℝd𝐱superscriptℝ𝑑\mathbf{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}bold_x ∈ roman_ℝ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT such that {𝐱i∣pi>0}i∈[n]⊆𝔹⁢(𝐱,4⁢r^)subscriptconditional-setsubscript𝐱𝑖subscript𝑝𝑖0𝑖delimited-[]𝑛𝔹𝐱4^𝑟\{\mathbf{x}_{i}\mid p_{i}>0\}_{i\in[n]}\subseteq\mathbb{B}(\mathbf{x},4\hat{r}){ bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∣ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0 } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⊆ roman_𝔹 ( bold_x , 4 over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG ). Moreover, the event (8) occurs with probability ≥1−δ9absent1𝛿9\geq 1-\frac{\delta}{9}≥ 1 - divide start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG start_ARG 9 end_ARG.

Proof.

The first statement in (8) was proven in (7) to hold with probability δ18𝛿18\frac{\delta}{18}divide start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG start_ARG 18 end_ARG, and the second statement’s proof is identical to the first half up to changing constants, so we omit it. Conditioned on this event, every 𝐱isubscript𝐱𝑖\mathbf{x}_{i}bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with pi>0subscript𝑝𝑖0p_{i}>0italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0 has fi⋆>0.45⁢ksubscriptsuperscript𝑓⋆𝑖0.45𝑘f^{\star}_{i}>0.45kitalic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0.45 italic_k. Moreover, because Z>0.55⁢n𝑍0.55𝑛Z>0.55nitalic_Z > 0.55 italic_n, there exists some j∈[n]𝑗delimited-[]𝑛j\in[n]italic_j ∈ [ italic_n ] (i.e., with the maximum value of pjsubscript𝑝𝑗p_{j}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) such that pj>0.55subscript𝑝𝑗0.55p_{j}>0.55italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0.55, which implies fj>0.6⁢ksubscript𝑓𝑗0.6𝑘f_{j}>0.6kitalic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0.6 italic_k and thus fj⋆>0.55⁢ksubscriptsuperscript𝑓⋆𝑗0.55𝑘f^{\star}_{j}>0.55kitalic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0.55 italic_k.

So, we have shown that 𝔹⁢(𝐱j,2⁢r^)𝔹subscript𝐱𝑗2^𝑟\mathbb{B}(\mathbf{x}_{j},2\hat{r})roman_𝔹 ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , 2 over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG ) contains more than 0.55⁢n0.55𝑛0.55n0.55 italic_n points in 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D, and every surviving i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n]italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ] (i.e., with positive pisubscript𝑝𝑖p_{i}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) contains more than 0.45⁢n0.45𝑛0.45n0.45 italic_n points in 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D. Thus, 𝔹⁢(𝐱j,2⁢r^)𝔹subscript𝐱𝑗2^𝑟\mathbb{B}(\mathbf{x}_{j},2\hat{r})roman_𝔹 ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , 2 over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG ) and 𝔹⁢(𝐱i,2⁢r^)𝔹subscript𝐱𝑖2^𝑟\mathbb{B}(\mathbf{x}_{i},2\hat{r})roman_𝔹 ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , 2 over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG ) intersect, and in particular, 𝔹⁢(𝐱j,4⁢r^)𝔹subscript𝐱𝑗4^𝑟\mathbb{B}(\mathbf{x}_{j},4\hat{r})roman_𝔹 ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , 4 over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG ) contains every surviving point by the triangle inequality. ∎

We are now ready to prove a privacy bound on Algorithm 3.

Lemma 9.

If n≥20𝑛20n\geq 20italic_n ≥ 20, Algorithm 3 is (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)( italic_ϵ , italic_δ )-DP.

Proof.

Fix neighboring datasets 𝒟,𝒟′∈𝔹d⁢(R)n𝒟superscript𝒟′superscript𝔹𝑑superscript𝑅𝑛\mathcal{D},\mathcal{D}^{\prime}\in\mathbb{B}^{d}(R)^{n}caligraphic_D , caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ roman_𝔹 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_R ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and assume without loss that they differ in the nthsuperscript𝑛thn^{\text{th}}italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT th end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT entry 𝐱n≠𝐱n′subscript𝐱𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝐱′𝑛\mathbf{x}_{n}\neq\mathbf{x}^{\prime}_{n}bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≠ bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We will define 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A, an alternate variant of Algorithm 3, which we denote 𝒜¯¯𝒜\overline{\mathcal{A}}over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_A end_ARG, where we condition on the following two events occurring. First, the index n𝑛nitalic_n should occur at most 2⁢k2𝑘2k2 italic_k times in ⋃i∈[n−1]Sisubscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛1subscript𝑆𝑖\bigcup_{i\in[n-1]}S_{i}⋃ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_n - 1 ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Second, the implications (8) must hold. It is clear that the first described event occurs with probability ≥1−δ18absent1𝛿18\geq 1-\frac{\delta}{18}≥ 1 - divide start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG start_ARG 18 end_ARG by using Fact 1 with our choice of k𝑘kitalic_k, and we proved in Lemma 8 that the second described event occurs with probability ≥1−δ9absent1𝛿9\geq 1-\frac{\delta}{9}≥ 1 - divide start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG start_ARG 9 end_ARG. Thus, the total variation distance between 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A and 𝒜¯¯𝒜\overline{\mathcal{A}}over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_A end_ARG is at most δ6𝛿6\frac{\delta}{6}divide start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG start_ARG 6 end_ARG. We will prove that 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A is (ϵ,δ3)italic-ϵ𝛿3(\epsilon,\frac{\delta}{3})( italic_ϵ , divide start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG )-DP, from which Lemma 1 gives that 𝒜¯¯𝒜\overline{\mathcal{A}}over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_A end_ARG is (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)( italic_ϵ , italic_δ )-DP.

We begin by showing that according to 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A, the statistic Z+ξ−24ϵ⁢log⁡(24δ)𝑍𝜉24italic-ϵ24𝛿Z+\xi-\frac{24}{\epsilon}\log(\frac{24}{\delta})italic_Z + italic_ξ - divide start_ARG 24 end_ARG start_ARG italic_ϵ end_ARG roman_log ( divide start_ARG 24 end_ARG start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG ) satisfies (ϵ2,δ6)italic-ϵ2𝛿6(\frac{\epsilon}{2},\frac{\delta}{6})( divide start_ARG italic_ϵ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG , divide start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG start_ARG 6 end_ARG )-DP. To do so, we will prove that Z𝑍Zitalic_Z has sensitivity ≤12absent12\leq 12≤ 12, and then apply Fact 3. Recall that by assumption, when 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A is run the number of times n𝑛nitalic_n appears in ⋃i∈[n]Sisubscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛subscript𝑆𝑖\bigcup_{i\in[n]}S_{i}⋃ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is at most 2⁢k2𝑘2k2 italic_k. Thus, for coupled values of Z,Z′𝑍superscript𝑍′Z,Z^{\prime}italic_Z , italic_Z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT corresponding to 𝒟,𝒟′𝒟superscript𝒟′\mathcal{D},\mathcal{D}^{\prime}caligraphic_D , caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, where the coupling is over the random indices selected on Line 3,

Z−Z′≤10.25⁢k⁢(k−0)+10.25⁢k⁢(number of copies of ⁢n⁢ occurring in ⁢⋃i∈[n−1]Si)≤12.𝑍superscript𝑍′10.25𝑘𝑘010.25𝑘number of copies of 𝑛 occurring in subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛1subscript𝑆𝑖12Z-Z^{\prime}\leq\frac{1}{0.25k}\left(k-0\right)+\frac{1}{0.25k}\left(\text{% number of copies of }n\text{ occurring in }\bigcup_{i\in[n-1]}S_{i}\right)\leq 12.italic_Z - italic_Z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≤ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 0.25 italic_k end_ARG ( italic_k - 0 ) + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 0.25 italic_k end_ARG ( number of copies of italic_n occurring in ⋃ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_n - 1 ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ≤ 12 .

In fact, we note that the following stronger unsigned bound holds:

∑i∈[n]|pi−pi′|subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛subscript𝑝𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑝′𝑖\displaystyle\sum_{i\in[n]}|p_{i}-p^{\prime}_{i}|∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | ≤4+∑i∈[n−1]|pi−pi′|absent4subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛1subscript𝑝𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑝′𝑖\displaystyle\leq 4+\sum_{i\in[n-1]}|p_{i}-p^{\prime}_{i}|≤ 4 + ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_n - 1 ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | (9)
≤4+10.25⁢k⁢(number of copies of ⁢n⁢ occurring in ⁢⋃i∈[n−1]Si)≤12,absent410.25𝑘number of copies of 𝑛 occurring in subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛1subscript𝑆𝑖12\displaystyle\leq 4+\frac{1}{0.25k}\left(\text{number of copies of }n\text{ % occurring in }\bigcup_{i\in[n-1]}S_{i}\right)\leq 12,≤ 4 + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 0.25 italic_k end_ARG ( number of copies of italic_n occurring in ⋃ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_n - 1 ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ≤ 12 ,

because the clipping to the interval [0,1]01[0,1][ 0 , 1 ] in the definitions of pisubscript𝑝𝑖p_{i}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, pi′subscriptsuperscript𝑝′𝑖p^{\prime}_{i}italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can only improve |pi−pi′|subscript𝑝𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑝′𝑖|p_{i}-p^{\prime}_{i}|| italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT |, and the distance between the corresponding fi,fi′subscript𝑓𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑓′𝑖f_{i},f^{\prime}_{i}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is at most the number of copies of n𝑛nitalic_n occurring in them.

Now, it remains to bound the privacy loss of the rest of 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A, depending on whether Line 9 passes. If the algorithm terminates on Line 10, then there is no additional privacy loss.

Otherwise, suppose we enter the branch starting on Line 12. Our next step is to bound the sensitivity of 𝐱¯¯𝐱\bar{\mathbf{x}}over¯ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG. Observe that whenever this branch is entered, we necessarily have Z>0.55⁢n𝑍0.55𝑛Z>0.55nitalic_Z > 0.55 italic_n (and similarly, Z′>0.55⁢nsuperscript𝑍′0.55𝑛Z^{\prime}>0.55nitalic_Z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT > 0.55 italic_n), because Z+ξ−24ϵ⁢log⁡(24δ)≤Z𝑍𝜉24italic-ϵ24𝛿𝑍Z+\xi-\frac{24}{\epsilon}\log(\frac{24}{\delta})\leq Zitalic_Z + italic_ξ - divide start_ARG 24 end_ARG start_ARG italic_ϵ end_ARG roman_log ( divide start_ARG 24 end_ARG start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG ) ≤ italic_Z deterministically. Thus, Lemma 8 guarantees that in 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A, all 𝐱i∈𝒟subscript𝐱𝑖𝒟\mathbf{x}_{i}\in\mathcal{D}bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_D with pi>0subscript𝑝𝑖0p_{i}>0italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0 are contained in a ball of radius 4⁢r^4^𝑟4\hat{r}4 over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG, and similarly all surviving elements in 𝒟′superscript𝒟′\mathcal{D}^{\prime}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are contained in a ball of radius 4⁢r^4^𝑟4\hat{r}4 over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG. However, there are at least 0.55⁢n0.55𝑛0.55n0.55 italic_n surviving elements of both 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D and 𝒟′superscript𝒟′\mathcal{D}^{\prime}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and in particular, for the given range of n𝑛nitalic_n there are at least two common surviving elements (one of which must be shared). A ball of radius 8⁢r^8^𝑟8\hat{r}8 over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG around this element, which we denote 𝐱^^𝐱\hat{\mathbf{x}}over^ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG in the rest of the proof, contains all surviving elements in 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D (according to {pi}i∈[n]subscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖𝑖delimited-[]𝑛\{p_{i}\}_{i\in[n]}{ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) and in 𝒟′superscript𝒟′\mathcal{D}^{\prime}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (according to {pi′}i∈[n]subscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑝′𝑖𝑖delimited-[]𝑛\{p^{\prime}_{i}\}_{i\in[n]}{ italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT).

Now we wish to bound 𝐱¯−𝐱¯′¯𝐱superscript¯𝐱′\bar{\mathbf{x}}-\bar{\mathbf{x}}^{\prime}over¯ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG - over¯ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, where 𝐱¯′:=1Z′⁢∑i∈[n]pi′⁢𝐱i′assignsuperscript¯𝐱′1superscript𝑍′subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑝′𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝐱′𝑖\bar{\mathbf{x}}^{\prime}:=\frac{1}{Z^{\prime}}\sum_{i\in[n]}p^{\prime}_{i}% \mathbf{x}^{\prime}_{i}over¯ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We have shown that in 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A, |Z−Z′|≤12𝑍superscript𝑍′12|Z-Z^{\prime}|\leq 12| italic_Z - italic_Z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | ≤ 12 and min⁡(Z,Z′)≥0.55⁢n𝑍superscript𝑍′0.55𝑛\min(Z,Z^{\prime})\geq 0.55nroman_min ( italic_Z , italic_Z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ≥ 0.55 italic_n. For convenience, define 𝐲i:=𝐱i−𝐱^assignsubscript𝐲𝑖subscript𝐱𝑖^𝐱\mathbf{y}_{i}:=\mathbf{x}_{i}-\hat{\mathbf{x}}bold_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - over^ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG for all i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n]italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ], and similarly define 𝐲i′subscriptsuperscript𝐲′𝑖\mathbf{y}^{\prime}_{i}bold_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Recalling that all surviving elements of 𝒟∪𝒟′𝒟superscript𝒟′\mathcal{D}\cup\mathcal{D}^{\prime}caligraphic_D ∪ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are contained in 𝔹⁢(𝐱^,8⁢r^)𝔹^𝐱8^𝑟\mathbb{B}(\hat{\mathbf{x}},8\hat{r})roman_𝔹 ( over^ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG , 8 over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG ),

∥𝐱¯−𝐱¯′∥delimited-∥∥¯𝐱superscript¯𝐱′\displaystyle\left\lVert\bar{\mathbf{x}}-\bar{\mathbf{x}}^{\prime}\right\rVert∥ over¯ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG - over¯ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ =∥1Z⁢∑i∈[n]pi⁢𝐲i−1Z′⁢∑i∈[n]pi′⁢𝐲i′∥absentdelimited-∥∥1𝑍subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛subscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝐲𝑖1superscript𝑍′subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑝′𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝐲′𝑖\displaystyle=\left\lVert\frac{1}{Z}\sum_{i\in[n]}p_{i}\mathbf{y}_{i}-\frac{1}% {Z^{\prime}}\sum_{i\in[n]}p^{\prime}_{i}\mathbf{y}^{\prime}_{i}\right\rVert= ∥ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Z end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥
≤|1Z−1Z′|⁢∥∑i∈[n−1]pi⁢𝐲i∥+1Z′⁢∥∑i∈[n−1](pi−pi′)⁢𝐲i∥+pnZ⁢∥𝐲n∥+pn′Z′⁢∥𝐲n′∥absent1𝑍1superscript𝑍′delimited-∥∥subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛1subscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝐲𝑖1superscript𝑍′delimited-∥∥subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛1subscript𝑝𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑝′𝑖subscript𝐲𝑖subscript𝑝𝑛𝑍delimited-∥∥subscript𝐲𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑝′𝑛superscript𝑍′delimited-∥∥subscriptsuperscript𝐲′𝑛\displaystyle\leq\left|\frac{1}{Z}-\frac{1}{Z^{\prime}}\right|\left\lVert\sum_% {i\in[n-1]}p_{i}\mathbf{y}_{i}\right\rVert+\frac{1}{Z^{\prime}}\left\lVert\sum% _{i\in[n-1]}(p_{i}-p^{\prime}_{i})\mathbf{y}_{i}\right\rVert+\frac{p_{n}}{Z}% \left\lVert\mathbf{y}_{n}\right\rVert+\frac{p^{\prime}_{n}}{Z^{\prime}}\left% \lVert\mathbf{y}^{\prime}_{n}\right\rVert≤ | divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Z end_ARG - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG | ∥ ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_n - 1 ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ∥ ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_n - 1 ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) bold_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ + divide start_ARG italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_Z end_ARG ∥ bold_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ + divide start_ARG italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_Z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ∥ bold_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥
≤|Z′−ZZ′|⁢∥1Z⁢∑i∈[n−1]pi⁢𝐲i∥+8⁢r^0.55⁢n⁢∑i∈[n−1]|pi−pi′|+16⁢r^0.55⁢nabsentsuperscript𝑍′𝑍superscript𝑍′delimited-∥∥1𝑍subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛1subscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝐲𝑖8^𝑟0.55𝑛subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛1subscript𝑝𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑝′𝑖16^𝑟0.55𝑛\displaystyle\leq\left|\frac{Z^{\prime}-Z}{Z^{\prime}}\right|\left\lVert\frac{% 1}{Z}\sum_{i\in[n-1]}p_{i}\mathbf{y}_{i}\right\rVert+\frac{8\hat{r}}{0.55n}% \sum_{i\in[n-1]}|p_{i}-p^{\prime}_{i}|+\frac{16\hat{r}}{0.55n}≤ | divide start_ARG italic_Z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Z end_ARG start_ARG italic_Z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG | ∥ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Z end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_n - 1 ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ + divide start_ARG 8 over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG 0.55 italic_n end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_n - 1 ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | + divide start_ARG 16 over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG 0.55 italic_n end_ARG
≤96⁢r^0.55⁢n+104⁢r^0.55⁢n+16⁢r^0.55⁢n≤400⁢r^n.absent96^𝑟0.55𝑛104^𝑟0.55𝑛16^𝑟0.55𝑛400^𝑟𝑛\displaystyle\leq\frac{96\hat{r}}{0.55n}+\frac{104\hat{r}}{0.55n}+\frac{16\hat% {r}}{0.55n}\leq\frac{400\hat{r}}{n}.≤ divide start_ARG 96 over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG 0.55 italic_n end_ARG + divide start_ARG 104 over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG 0.55 italic_n end_ARG + divide start_ARG 16 over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG 0.55 italic_n end_ARG ≤ divide start_ARG 400 over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG .

The first line shifted both 𝐱¯¯𝐱\bar{\mathbf{x}}over¯ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG and 𝐱¯′superscript¯𝐱′\bar{\mathbf{x}}^{\prime}over¯ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT by 𝐱^^𝐱\hat{\mathbf{x}}over^ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG, and the second line applied the triangle inequality. The third line applied the triangle inequality to the middle term, and bounded the contribution of 𝐲nsubscript𝐲𝑛\mathbf{y}_{n}bold_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT by using that ∥𝐲n∥≤8⁢r^delimited-∥∥subscript𝐲𝑛8^𝑟\left\lVert\mathbf{y}_{n}\right\rVert\leq 8\hat{r}∥ bold_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ ≤ 8 over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG if pn>0subscript𝑝𝑛0p_{n}>0italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0; a similar bound applies to 𝐲n′subscriptsuperscript𝐲′𝑛\mathbf{y}^{\prime}_{n}bold_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. In the fourth line, we used the triangle inequality on the first term, as well as that ∑i∈[n−1]|pi−pi′|≤1+12subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛1subscript𝑝𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑝′𝑖112\sum_{i\in[n-1]}|p_{i}-p^{\prime}_{i}|\leq 1+12∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_n - 1 ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | ≤ 1 + 12 by using (9) and accounting for the nthsuperscript𝑛thn^{\text{th}}italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT th end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT point separately. Thus, 𝐱¯¯𝐱\bar{\mathbf{x}}over¯ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG has sensitivity 400⁢r^n400^𝑟𝑛\frac{400\hat{r}}{n}divide start_ARG 400 over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG in 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A. Fact 2 now guarantees that Line 19 is also (ϵ2,δ6)italic-ϵ2𝛿6(\frac{\epsilon}{2},\frac{\delta}{6})( divide start_ARG italic_ϵ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG , divide start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG start_ARG 6 end_ARG )-DP. ∎

We now combine our developments to give our constant-factor approximation to the geometric median.

Theorem 3.

Let 𝒟={𝐱i}i∈[n]⊂𝔹d⁢(R)𝒟subscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖𝑖delimited-[]𝑛superscript𝔹𝑑𝑅\mathcal{D}=\{\mathbf{x}_{i}\}_{i\in[n]}\subset\mathbb{B}^{d}(R)caligraphic_D = { bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⊂ roman_𝔹 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_R ) for R>0𝑅0R>0italic_R > 0, let 0<r≤4⁢r(0.9)⁢(𝒟)0𝑟4superscript𝑟0.9𝒟0<r\leq 4r^{(0.9)}(\mathcal{D})0 < italic_r ≤ 4 italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0.9 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( caligraphic_D ), and let (ϵ,δ)∈[0,1]2italic-ϵ𝛿superscript012(\epsilon,\delta)\in[0,1]^{2}( italic_ϵ , italic_δ ) ∈ [ 0 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Suppose that

n≥C⋅(d⁢log⁡(1δ)ϵ+log⁡(log⁡(Rr)δ)ϵ),𝑛⋅𝐶𝑑1𝛿italic-ϵ𝑅𝑟𝛿italic-ϵn\geq C\cdot\left(\frac{\sqrt{d}\log(\frac{1}{\delta})}{\epsilon}+\frac{\log% \left(\frac{\log(\frac{R}{r})}{\delta}\right)}{\epsilon}\right),italic_n ≥ italic_C ⋅ ( divide start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_d end_ARG roman_log ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_ϵ end_ARG + divide start_ARG roman_log ( divide start_ARG roman_log ( divide start_ARG italic_R end_ARG start_ARG italic_r end_ARG ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_ϵ end_ARG ) ,

for a sufficiently large constant C𝐶Citalic_C. There is an (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)( italic_ϵ , italic_δ )-DP algorithm (Algorithm 3 using Algorithm 2 to compute the parameter r^^𝑟\hat{r}over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG) that returns (𝐱^,r^)^𝐱^𝑟(\hat{\mathbf{x}},\hat{r})( over^ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG , over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG ) such that with probability ≥1−δabsent1𝛿\geq 1-\delta≥ 1 - italic_δ, following notation (3),

f𝒟⁢(𝐱^)≤(40⁢C′+1)⁢f𝒟⁢(𝐱⋆⁢(𝒟)),r^≤4⁢r(0.9),formulae-sequencesubscript𝑓𝒟^𝐱40superscript𝐶′1subscript𝑓𝒟subscript𝐱⋆𝒟^𝑟4superscript𝑟0.9f_{\mathcal{D}}(\hat{\mathbf{x}})\leq(40C^{\prime}+1)f_{\mathcal{D}}(\mathbf{x% }_{\star}(\mathcal{D})),\;\hat{r}\leq 4r^{(0.9)},italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over^ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG ) ≤ ( 40 italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 1 ) italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_D ) ) , over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG ≤ 4 italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0.9 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , (10)

for a universal constant C′superscript𝐶′C^{\prime}italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Moreover, ∥𝐱⋆⁢(𝒟)−𝐱^∥≤C′⁢r^delimited-∥∥subscript𝐱⋆𝒟^𝐱superscript𝐶′^𝑟\left\lVert\mathbf{x}_{\star}(\mathcal{D})-\hat{\mathbf{x}}\right\rVert\leq C^% {\prime}\hat{r}∥ bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_D ) - over^ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG ∥ ≤ italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG. The algorithm runs in time

O⁢(n⁢d⁢log⁡(Rr)⁢log⁡(n⁢log⁡(Rr)δ)).𝑂𝑛𝑑𝑅𝑟𝑛𝑅𝑟𝛿O\left(nd\log\left(\frac{R}{r}\right)\log\left(\frac{n\log(\frac{R}{r})}{% \delta}\right)\right).italic_O ( italic_n italic_d roman_log ( divide start_ARG italic_R end_ARG start_ARG italic_r end_ARG ) roman_log ( divide start_ARG italic_n roman_log ( divide start_ARG italic_R end_ARG start_ARG italic_r end_ARG ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG ) ) .
Proof.

Regarding the utility bound, we will only establish that ∥𝐱⋆⁢(𝒟)−𝐱^∥≤C′⁢r^delimited-∥∥subscript𝐱⋆𝒟^𝐱superscript𝐶′^𝑟\left\lVert\mathbf{x}_{\star}(\mathcal{D})-\hat{\mathbf{x}}\right\rVert\leq C^% {\prime}\hat{r}∥ bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_D ) - over^ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG ∥ ≤ italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG, which also gives (10) upon observing that f𝒟subscript𝑓𝒟f_{\mathcal{D}}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is 1111-Lipschitz, and f𝒟⁢(𝐱⋆⁢(𝒟))≥0.1⁢r(0.9)⁢(𝒟)subscript𝑓𝒟subscript𝐱⋆𝒟0.1superscript𝑟0.9𝒟f_{\mathcal{D}}(\mathbf{x}_{\star}(\mathcal{D}))\geq 0.1r^{(0.9)}(\mathcal{D})italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_D ) ) ≥ 0.1 italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0.9 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( caligraphic_D ), due to Lemma 3.

We first run Algorithm 2 with parameters (ϵ,δ)←(ϵ2,δ2)←italic-ϵ𝛿italic-ϵ2𝛿2(\epsilon,\delta)\leftarrow(\frac{\epsilon}{2},\frac{\delta}{2})( italic_ϵ , italic_δ ) ← ( divide start_ARG italic_ϵ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG , divide start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ), which gives for large enough C𝐶Citalic_C (via Lemma 6)

14⁢r(0.75)≤r^≤4⁢r(0.9),14superscript𝑟0.75^𝑟4superscript𝑟0.9\frac{1}{4}r^{(0.75)}\leq\hat{r}\leq 4r^{(0.9)},divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0.75 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≤ over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG ≤ 4 italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0.9 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , (11)

with probability ≥1−δ2absent1𝛿2\geq 1-\frac{\delta}{2}≥ 1 - divide start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG. Next, we run Algorithm 3 with this value of r^^𝑟\hat{r}over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG, and parameters (ϵ,δ)←(ϵ2,δ2)←italic-ϵ𝛿italic-ϵ2𝛿2(\epsilon,\delta)\leftarrow(\frac{\epsilon}{2},\frac{\delta}{2})( italic_ϵ , italic_δ ) ← ( divide start_ARG italic_ϵ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG , divide start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ). The privacy of composing these two algorithms now follows from Lemmas 5 and 9, and the runtime follows from Lemma 6, because Algorithm 2’s runtime does not dominate upon inspection.

It remains to argue about the utility, i.e., that ∥𝐱⋆⁢(𝒟)−𝐱^∥≤C′⁢r^delimited-∥∥subscript𝐱⋆𝒟^𝐱superscript𝐶′^𝑟\left\lVert\mathbf{x}_{\star}(\mathcal{D})-\hat{\mathbf{x}}\right\rVert\leq C^% {\prime}\hat{r}∥ bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_D ) - over^ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG ∥ ≤ italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG. Conditioned on (11) holding, Lemma 6 guarantees that with probability ≥1−δ4absent1𝛿4\geq 1-\frac{\delta}{4}≥ 1 - divide start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG, we have that ∥𝐱¯−𝐱⋆⁢(𝒟)∥≤3⁢r^delimited-∥∥¯𝐱subscript𝐱⋆𝒟3^𝑟\left\lVert\bar{\mathbf{x}}-\mathbf{x}_{\star}(\mathcal{D})\right\rVert\leq 3% \hat{r}∥ over¯ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_D ) ∥ ≤ 3 over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG, as a positively-weighted average of points in 𝔹d⁢(𝐱⋆⁢(𝒟),3⁢r^)superscript𝔹𝑑subscript𝐱⋆𝒟3^𝑟\mathbb{B}^{d}(\mathbf{x}_{\star}(\mathcal{D}),3\hat{r})roman_𝔹 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_D ) , 3 over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG ). Finally, for the given value of σ𝜎\sigmaitalic_σ in Algorithm 2, standard Gaussian concentration bounds imply that with probability ≥1−δ4absent1𝛿4\geq 1-\frac{\delta}{4}≥ 1 - divide start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG,

∥𝐱¯−𝐱^∥=∥𝝃∥≤3⁢σ⁢d⁢log⁡(4δ)=O⁢(r^⋅d⁢log⁡(1δ)n⁢ϵ)=O⁢(r^).delimited-∥∥¯𝐱^𝐱delimited-∥∥𝝃3𝜎𝑑4𝛿𝑂⋅^𝑟𝑑1𝛿𝑛italic-ϵ𝑂^𝑟\left\lVert\bar{\mathbf{x}}-\hat{\mathbf{x}}\right\rVert=\left\lVert% \boldsymbol{\xi}\right\rVert\leq 3\sigma\sqrt{d\log\left(\frac{4}{\delta}% \right)}=O\left(\hat{r}\cdot\frac{\sqrt{d}\log(\frac{1}{\delta})}{n\epsilon}% \right)=O(\hat{r}).∥ over¯ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG - over^ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG ∥ = ∥ bold_italic_ξ ∥ ≤ 3 italic_σ square-root start_ARG italic_d roman_log ( divide start_ARG 4 end_ARG start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG ) end_ARG = italic_O ( over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG ⋅ divide start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_d end_ARG roman_log ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_n italic_ϵ end_ARG ) = italic_O ( over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG ) .

Thus, ∥𝐱⋆⁢(𝒟)−𝐱^∥≤C′⁢r^delimited-∥∥subscript𝐱⋆𝒟^𝐱superscript𝐶′^𝑟\left\lVert\mathbf{x}_{\star}(\mathcal{D})-\hat{\mathbf{x}}\right\rVert\leq C^% {\prime}\hat{r}∥ bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_D ) - over^ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG ∥ ≤ italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG holds for an appropriate C′superscript𝐶′C^{\prime}italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, except with probability δ𝛿\deltaitalic_δ. ∎

We remark that Theorem 3 actually comes with the slightly stronger guarantee that we obtain the optimal value for the geometric median objective f𝒟subscript𝑓𝒟f_{\mathcal{D}}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, up to an additive error scaling as O⁢(r(0.9))𝑂superscript𝑟0.9O(r^{(0.9)})italic_O ( italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0.9 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). In general, while r(0.9)=O⁢(f𝒟⁢(𝐱⋆⁢(𝒟)))superscript𝑟0.9𝑂subscript𝑓𝒟subscript𝐱⋆𝒟r^{(0.9)}=O(f_{\mathcal{D}}(\mathbf{x}_{\star}(\mathcal{D})))italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0.9 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_O ( italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_D ) ) ) is always true by Lemma 3, it is possible that r(0.9)≪f𝒟⁢(𝐱⋆⁢(𝒟))much-less-thansuperscript𝑟0.9subscript𝑓𝒟subscript𝐱⋆𝒟r^{(0.9)}\ll f_{\mathcal{D}}(\mathbf{x}_{\star}(\mathcal{D}))italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0.9 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≪ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_D ) ) if a small fraction of outlier points contributes significantly to the objective. We also note that for datasets where we have more a priori information on the number of outliers we expect to see, we can adjust the quantile 0.90.90.90.9 in Theorem 3 to be any quantile >0.5absent0.5>0.5> 0.5 by appropriately adjusting constants.

4 Boosting Approximations via Stable DP-SGD

In this section, we give a DP algorithm that efficiently minimizes the geometric median objective (3) over a domain 𝔹d⁢(𝐱¯,r^)superscript𝔹𝑑¯𝐱^𝑟\mathbb{B}^{d}(\bar{\mathbf{x}},\hat{r})roman_𝔹 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( over¯ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG , over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG ), given a dataset 𝒟:={𝐱i}i∈[n]assign𝒟subscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖𝑖delimited-[]𝑛\mathcal{D}:=\{\mathbf{x}_{i}\}_{i\in[n]}caligraphic_D := { bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. In our final application to the geometric median problem, the optimization domain (i.e., the parameters 𝐱¯∈ℝd¯𝐱superscriptℝ𝑑\bar{\mathbf{x}}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}over¯ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG ∈ roman_ℝ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and r^∈ℝ≥0^𝑟subscriptℝabsent0\hat{r}\in\mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG ∈ roman_ℝ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) will be privately estimated using Theorem 3, such that with high probability r^=O⁢(f𝒟⁢(𝐱⋆⁢(𝒟)))^𝑟𝑂subscript𝑓𝒟subscript𝐱⋆𝒟\hat{r}=O(f_{\mathcal{D}}(\mathbf{x}_{\star}(\mathcal{D})))over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG = italic_O ( italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_D ) ) ) and ∥𝐱−𝐱⋆⁢(𝒟)∥≤r^delimited-∥∥𝐱subscript𝐱⋆𝒟^𝑟\left\lVert\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}_{\star}(\mathcal{D})\right\rVert\leq\hat{r}∥ bold_x - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_D ) ∥ ≤ over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG. In the meantime, we treat the domain 𝔹d⁢(𝐱¯,r^)superscript𝔹𝑑¯𝐱^𝑟\mathbb{B}^{d}(\bar{\mathbf{x}},\hat{r})roman_𝔹 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( over¯ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG , over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG ) as a public input here.

Our strategy is to use a localization framework given by [FKT20], which gives a query-efficient reduction from private DP-SGD to stable DP-SGD executed in phases. Specifically, observe that outputting555By default, if 𝐱=𝐱i𝐱subscript𝐱𝑖\mathbf{x}=\mathbf{x}_{i}bold_x = bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we let (12) evaluate to 𝟎dsubscript0𝑑\mathbf{0}_{d}bold_0 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which is a valid subgradient by first-order optimality.

𝐳−𝐱i∥𝐳−𝐱i∥=∇∥⋅−𝐱i∥(𝐳)\frac{\mathbf{z}-\mathbf{x}_{i}}{\left\lVert\mathbf{z}-\mathbf{x}_{i}\right% \rVert}=\nabla\left\lVert\cdot-\mathbf{x}_{i}\right\rVert\left(\mathbf{z}\right)divide start_ARG bold_z - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ∥ bold_z - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ end_ARG = ∇ ∥ ⋅ - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ ( bold_z ) (12)

for a uniformly random i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n]italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ] is unbiased for a subgradient of f𝒟⁢(𝐳)subscript𝑓𝒟𝐳f_{\mathcal{D}}(\mathbf{z})italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_z ). This leads us to define the following Algorithm 4 patterned off the [FKT20] framework, whose privacy is analyzed in Section 4.1 using a custom stability argument, and whose utility is analyzed in Section 4.2.

Algorithm 4 proceeds in K≈log⁡(T)𝐾𝑇K\approx\log(T)italic_K ≈ roman_log ( italic_T ) phases. In each phase (loop of Lines 2 to 18) other than k=1𝑘1k=1italic_k = 1, we define a domain 𝒦(k)superscript𝒦𝑘\mathcal{K}^{(k)}caligraphic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT centered at the output of the previous phase with geometrically shrinking radius ∝σ(k)proportional-toabsentsuperscript𝜎𝑘\propto\sigma^{(k)}∝ italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT; the domain for phase k=1𝑘1k=1italic_k = 1 is simply 𝔹d⁢(𝐱¯,r^)superscript𝔹𝑑¯𝐱^𝑟\mathbb{B}^{d}(\bar{\mathbf{x}},\hat{r})roman_𝔹 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( over¯ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG , over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG ). After this, we take T(k)superscript𝑇𝑘T^{(k)}italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT steps of SGD over 𝒦(k)superscript𝒦𝑘\mathcal{K}^{(k)}caligraphic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with step size η(k)superscript𝜂𝑘\eta^{(k)}italic_η start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and output a noised variant of the average iterate in Lines 15 to 17.

Remark 1.

Several steps in Algorithm 4 are used only in the worst-case utility proof, and do not affect privacy. Practical optimizations can be made while preserving privacy guarantees, e.g., removing projections onto the changing domains 𝒦(k)superscript𝒦𝑘\mathcal{K}^{(k)}caligraphic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT rather than 𝒦(1)superscript𝒦1\mathcal{K}^{(1)}caligraphic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, which is not used in the privacy proof.

One optimization we found useful in our experiments (described in Section 5) is replacing the random sampling on Line 12 with deterministic passes through the dataset in a fixed order. By doing so, we know the total number of accesses of any single element is ≤m:=⌈Tn⌉absent𝑚assign𝑇𝑛\leq m:=\lceil\frac{T}{n}\rceil≤ italic_m := ⌈ divide start_ARG italic_T end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG ⌉ (rather than the high-probability estimate in Lemma 10 for the randomized variant in Algorithm 4). This lets us tighten the noise level σ(k)superscript𝜎𝑘\sigma^{(k)}italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT by a fairly significant constant factor, resulting in improved empirical performance.

4.1 Privacy of Algorithm 4

In this section, we show that Algorithm 4 satisfies (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)( italic_ϵ , italic_δ )-DP for an appropriate choice of ρ𝜌\rhoitalic_ρ. When the sample functions of interest are smooth (i.e., have bounded second derivative), [FKT20] gives a proof based on the contractivity of iterates. This is based on the observation that gradient descent steps with respect to a smooth function are contractive for an appropriate step size (see e.g., Proposition 2.10, [FKT20]). Unfortunately, our sample functions are of the form ∥⋅−𝐱i∥\left\lVert\cdot-\mathbf{x}_{i}\right\rVert∥ ⋅ - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥, which are not even differentiable, let alone smooth. Nonetheless, we inductively prove approximate contractivity of Algorithm 4’s iterates by opening up the analysis and using the structure of the geometric median objective.

Throughout, we fix neighboring 𝒟,𝒟′∈(ℝd)n𝒟superscript𝒟′superscriptsuperscriptℝ𝑑𝑛\mathcal{D},\mathcal{D}^{\prime}\in(\mathbb{R}^{d})^{n}caligraphic_D , caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ ( roman_ℝ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and assume without loss of generality they differ in the nthsuperscript𝑛thn^{\text{th}}italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT th end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT entry. To simplify notation, we let ℐ∈[n]Tℐsuperscriptdelimited-[]𝑛𝑇\mathcal{I}\in[n]^{T}caligraphic_I ∈ [ italic_n ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT denote the multiset of T𝑇Titalic_T indices sampled in Line 12, across all phases. We prove DP of Algorithm 4 via appealing to Lemma 1, where we let 𝒜¯¯𝒜\overline{\mathcal{A}}over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_A end_ARG denote Algorithm 4, and we let 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A denote a variant of Algorithm 4 conditioned on ℐℐ\mathcal{I}caligraphic_I containing at most m:=3⁢(Tn+log⁡(8δ))assign𝑚3𝑇𝑛8𝛿m:=3(\frac{T}{n}+\log(\frac{8}{\delta}))italic_m := 3 ( divide start_ARG italic_T end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG + roman_log ( divide start_ARG 8 end_ARG start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG ) ) copies of n𝑛nitalic_n. We first bound the total variation distance between 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A and 𝒜¯¯𝒜\overline{\mathcal{A}}over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_A end_ARG using Fact 1.

Lemma 10.

With probability ≥1−δ8absent1𝛿8\geq 1-\frac{\delta}{8}≥ 1 - divide start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG start_ARG 8 end_ARG, Algorithm 4 yields ℐℐ\mathcal{I}caligraphic_I containing ≤mabsent𝑚\leq m≤ italic_m copies of n𝑛nitalic_n.

Proof.

In expectation, we have Tn≥1𝑇𝑛1\frac{T}{n}\geq 1divide start_ARG italic_T end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG ≥ 1 copies, so the result follows from Fact 1 and our choice of m𝑚mitalic_m. ∎

We will show that 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A is (ϵ,δ2)italic-ϵ𝛿2(\epsilon,\frac{\delta}{2})( italic_ϵ , divide start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG )-DP, upon which Lemmas 1 and 10 imply that 𝒜¯¯𝒜\overline{\mathcal{A}}over¯ start_ARG caligraphic_A end_ARG (Algorithm 4) is (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)( italic_ϵ , italic_δ )-DP. To do so, we control the sensitivity of each iterate 𝐳t(k)superscriptsubscript𝐳𝑡𝑘\mathbf{z}_{t}^{(k)}bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, using the following two helper facts.

Fact 5 ([Roc76]).

Let 𝒦⊂ℝd𝒦superscriptℝ𝑑\mathcal{K}\subset\mathbb{R}^{d}caligraphic_K ⊂ roman_ℝ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be a compact, convex set. Then for any 𝐱,𝐲∈ℝd𝐱𝐲superscriptℝ𝑑\mathbf{x},\mathbf{y}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}bold_x , bold_y ∈ roman_ℝ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we have

∥𝚷𝒦⁢(𝐱)−𝚷𝒦⁢(𝐲)∥≤∥𝐱−𝐲∥.delimited-∥∥subscript𝚷𝒦𝐱subscript𝚷𝒦𝐲delimited-∥∥𝐱𝐲\left\lVert\boldsymbol{\Pi}_{\mathcal{K}}(\mathbf{x})-\boldsymbol{\Pi}_{% \mathcal{K}}(\mathbf{y})\right\rVert\leq\left\lVert\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{y}\right\rVert.∥ bold_Π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) - bold_Π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_y ) ∥ ≤ ∥ bold_x - bold_y ∥ .
Lemma 11.

For any unit vectors 𝐮,𝐯∈ℝd𝐮𝐯superscriptℝ𝑑\mathbf{u},\mathbf{v}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}bold_u , bold_v ∈ roman_ℝ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and a,b>0𝑎𝑏0a,b>0italic_a , italic_b > 0, let 𝐱=a⁢𝐮𝐱𝑎𝐮\mathbf{x}=a\mathbf{u}bold_x = italic_a bold_u and 𝐲=b⁢𝐯𝐲𝑏𝐯\mathbf{y}=b\mathbf{v}bold_y = italic_b bold_v. Then, letting 𝐱′←(a−η)⁢𝐮←superscript𝐱′𝑎𝜂𝐮\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\leftarrow(a-\eta)\mathbf{u}bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ← ( italic_a - italic_η ) bold_u and 𝐲′←(b−η)⁢𝐯←superscript𝐲′𝑏𝜂𝐯\mathbf{y}^{\prime}\leftarrow(b-\eta)\mathbf{v}bold_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ← ( italic_b - italic_η ) bold_v, we have ∥𝐱′−𝐲′∥≤max⁡(∥𝐱−𝐲∥,3⁢η)delimited-∥∥superscript𝐱′superscript𝐲′delimited-∥∥𝐱𝐲3𝜂\left\lVert\mathbf{x}^{\prime}-\mathbf{y}^{\prime}\right\rVert\leq\max(\left% \lVert\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{y}\right\rVert,3\eta)∥ bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - bold_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ ≤ roman_max ( ∥ bold_x - bold_y ∥ , 3 italic_η ).

Proof.

We claim that

∥𝐱′−𝐲′∥≤∥𝐱−𝐲∥⇔a+b≥η,iffdelimited-∥∥superscript𝐱′superscript𝐲′delimited-∥∥𝐱𝐲𝑎𝑏𝜂\left\lVert\mathbf{x}^{\prime}-\mathbf{y}^{\prime}\right\rVert\leq\left\lVert% \mathbf{x}-\mathbf{y}\right\rVert\iff a+b\geq\eta,∥ bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - bold_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ ≤ ∥ bold_x - bold_y ∥ ⇔ italic_a + italic_b ≥ italic_η , (13)

from which the proof follows from observing that if a+b≤η𝑎𝑏𝜂a+b\leq\etaitalic_a + italic_b ≤ italic_η, then we can trivially bound ∥𝐱′−𝐲′∥≤∥𝐱−𝐲∥+2⁢η≤a+b+2⁢η≤3⁢ηdelimited-∥∥superscript𝐱′superscript𝐲′delimited-∥∥𝐱𝐲2𝜂𝑎𝑏2𝜂3𝜂\left\lVert\mathbf{x}^{\prime}-\mathbf{y}^{\prime}\right\rVert\leq\left\lVert% \mathbf{x}-\mathbf{y}\right\rVert+2\eta\leq a+b+2\eta\leq 3\eta∥ bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - bold_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ ≤ ∥ bold_x - bold_y ∥ + 2 italic_η ≤ italic_a + italic_b + 2 italic_η ≤ 3 italic_η. Indeed, (13) follows from a direct expansion:

∥𝐱−𝐲∥2−∥𝐱′−𝐲′∥2superscriptdelimited-∥∥𝐱𝐲2superscriptdelimited-∥∥superscript𝐱′superscript𝐲′2\displaystyle\left\lVert\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{y}\right\rVert^{2}-\left\lVert% \mathbf{x}^{\prime}-\mathbf{y}^{\prime}\right\rVert^{2}∥ bold_x - bold_y ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - ∥ bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - bold_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT =a2+b2−2⁢a⁢b⁢⟨𝐮,𝐯⟩−(a−η)2−(b−η)2+2⁢(a−η)⁢(b−η)⁢⟨𝐮,𝐯⟩absentsuperscript𝑎2superscript𝑏22𝑎𝑏𝐮𝐯superscript𝑎𝜂2superscript𝑏𝜂22𝑎𝜂𝑏𝜂𝐮𝐯\displaystyle=a^{2}+b^{2}-2ab\left\langle\mathbf{u},\mathbf{v}\right\rangle-(a% -\eta)^{2}-(b-\eta)^{2}+2(a-\eta)(b-\eta)\left\langle\mathbf{u},\mathbf{v}\right\rangle= italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 2 italic_a italic_b ⟨ bold_u , bold_v ⟩ - ( italic_a - italic_η ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - ( italic_b - italic_η ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 2 ( italic_a - italic_η ) ( italic_b - italic_η ) ⟨ bold_u , bold_v ⟩
=2⁢η⁢(a+b)−2⁢η2−2⁢η⁢(a+b)⁢⟨𝐮,𝐯⟩+2⁢η2⁢⟨𝐮,𝐯⟩absent2𝜂𝑎𝑏2superscript𝜂22𝜂𝑎𝑏𝐮𝐯2superscript𝜂2𝐮𝐯\displaystyle=2\eta(a+b)-2\eta^{2}-2\eta(a+b)\left\langle\mathbf{u},\mathbf{v}% \right\rangle+2\eta^{2}\left\langle\mathbf{u},\mathbf{v}\right\rangle= 2 italic_η ( italic_a + italic_b ) - 2 italic_η start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 2 italic_η ( italic_a + italic_b ) ⟨ bold_u , bold_v ⟩ + 2 italic_η start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⟨ bold_u , bold_v ⟩
=2⁢η⁢(a+b−η)⁢(1−⟨𝐮,𝐯⟩).absent2𝜂𝑎𝑏𝜂1𝐮𝐯\displaystyle=2\eta(a+b-\eta)(1-\left\langle\mathbf{u},\mathbf{v}\right\rangle).= 2 italic_η ( italic_a + italic_b - italic_η ) ( 1 - ⟨ bold_u , bold_v ⟩ ) .

Thus, for η≥0𝜂0\eta\geq 0italic_η ≥ 0 and ⟨𝐮,𝐯⟩≥0𝐮𝐯0\left\langle\mathbf{u},\mathbf{v}\right\rangle\geq 0⟨ bold_u , bold_v ⟩ ≥ 0, we conclude that (13) holds. ∎

Corollary 1.

For any phase k∈[K]𝑘delimited-[]𝐾k\in[K]italic_k ∈ [ italic_K ] in Algorithm 4, condition on the value of 𝐳0(k)superscriptsubscript𝐳0𝑘\mathbf{z}_{0}^{(k)}bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and assume that ℐℐ\mathcal{I}caligraphic_I contains at most m𝑚mitalic_m copies of n𝑛nitalic_n. Then for any 0≤t<Tk0𝑡subscript𝑇𝑘0\leq t<T_{k}0 ≤ italic_t < italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the sensitivity of 𝐳t(k)superscriptsubscript𝐳𝑡𝑘\mathbf{z}_{t}^{(k)}bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is ≤(2⁢m+1)⁢η(k)absent2𝑚1superscript𝜂𝑘\leq(2m+1)\eta^{(k)}≤ ( 2 italic_m + 1 ) italic_η start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Proof.

Throughout this proof only, we drop the iteration k𝑘kitalic_k from superscripts for notational simplicity, so we let T:=T(k)assign𝑇superscript𝑇𝑘T:=T^{(k)}italic_T := italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and η:=η(k)assign𝜂superscript𝜂𝑘\eta:=\eta^{(k)}italic_η := italic_η start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, referring to the relevant iterates as {𝐳t}0≤t<T:={𝐳t(k)}0≤t<T(k)assignsubscriptsubscript𝐳𝑡0𝑡𝑇subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝐳𝑡𝑘0𝑡superscript𝑇𝑘\{\mathbf{z}_{t}\}_{0\leq t<T}:=\{\mathbf{z}_{t}^{(k)}\}_{0\leq t<T^{(k)}}{ bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 ≤ italic_t < italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := { bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 ≤ italic_t < italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We also refer to the index i𝑖iitalic_i selected on Line 12 in iteration 0≤t<T0𝑡𝑇0\leq t<T0 ≤ italic_t < italic_T by itsubscript𝑖𝑡i_{t}italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Fix two copies of the kthsuperscript𝑘thk^{\text{th}}italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT th end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT phase of Algorithm 4, both initialized at 𝐳0subscript𝐳0\mathbf{z}_{0}bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, but using neighboring datasets 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D, 𝒟′superscript𝒟′\mathcal{D}^{\prime}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT differing in the nthsuperscript𝑛thn^{\text{th}}italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT th end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT entry. Also, fix a realization of {it}0≤t<Tsubscriptsubscript𝑖𝑡0𝑡𝑇\{i_{t}\}_{0\leq t<T}{ italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 ≤ italic_t < italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, such that it=nsubscript𝑖𝑡𝑛i_{t}=nitalic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_n at most m𝑚mitalic_m choices of t𝑡titalic_t (note that m𝑚mitalic_m is actually a bound on how many times it=nsubscript𝑖𝑡𝑛i_{t}=nitalic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_n across all phases, so it certainly bounds the occurrence count in a single phase). Conditioned on this realization, Algorithm 4 is now a deterministic mapping from 𝐳0subscript𝐳0\mathbf{z}_{0}bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to the iterates {𝐳t}0≤t<Tsubscriptsubscript𝐳𝑡0𝑡𝑇\{\mathbf{z}_{t}\}_{0\leq t<T}{ bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 ≤ italic_t < italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, depending on the dataset used.

Denote the iterates given by the dataset 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D by {𝐳t}0≤t<Tsubscriptsubscript𝐳𝑡0𝑡𝑇\{\mathbf{z}_{t}\}_{0\leq t<T}{ bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 ≤ italic_t < italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the iterates given by 𝒟′superscript𝒟′\mathcal{D}^{\prime}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT by {𝐳t′}0≤t<Tsubscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝐳′𝑡0𝑡𝑇\{\mathbf{z}^{\prime}_{t}\}_{0\leq t<T}{ bold_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 ≤ italic_t < italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, so that 𝐳0=𝐳0′subscript𝐳0subscriptsuperscript𝐳′0\mathbf{z}_{0}=\mathbf{z}^{\prime}_{0}bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT by assumption. Also, let Φt:=∥𝐳t−𝐳t′∥assignsubscriptΦ𝑡delimited-∥∥subscript𝐳𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝐳′𝑡\Phi_{t}:=\left\lVert\mathbf{z}_{t}-\mathbf{z}^{\prime}_{t}\right\rVertroman_Φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := ∥ bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ for all 0≤t<T0𝑡𝑇0\leq t<T0 ≤ italic_t < italic_T. We claim that for all 0≤t<T0𝑡𝑇0\leq t<T0 ≤ italic_t < italic_T,

Φt≤max⁡(2⁢mt+1,3)⁢η, where ⁢mt:=∑0≤s<t𝕀is=n,formulae-sequencesubscriptΦ𝑡2subscript𝑚𝑡13𝜂assign where subscript𝑚𝑡subscript0𝑠𝑡subscript𝕀subscript𝑖𝑠𝑛\Phi_{t}\leq\max(2m_{t}+1,3)\eta,\text{ where }m_{t}:=\sum_{0\leq s<t}\mathbb{% I}_{i_{s}=n},roman_Φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ roman_max ( 2 italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 , 3 ) italic_η , where italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 ≤ italic_s < italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_𝕀 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (14)

i.e., mtsubscript𝑚𝑡m_{t}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the number of times the index n𝑛nitalic_n was sampled in the first t𝑡titalic_t iterations of the phase. If we can show (14) holds, then we are done because mt≤msubscript𝑚𝑡𝑚m_{t}\leq mitalic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ italic_m by assumption.

We are left with proving (14), which we do by induction. The base case t=0𝑡0t=0italic_t = 0 is clear. Suppose (14) holds at iteration t𝑡titalic_t. In iteration t+1𝑡1t+1italic_t + 1, if mt+1=mt+1subscript𝑚𝑡1subscript𝑚𝑡1m_{t+1}=m_{t}+1italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 (i.e., it=nsubscript𝑖𝑡𝑛i_{t}=nitalic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_n was sampled), then (14) holds by the triangle inequality and the induction hypothesis, because all gradient steps η⁢𝐠t𝜂subscript𝐠𝑡\eta\mathbf{g}_{t}italic_η bold_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT have ∥η⁢𝐠t∥≤ηdelimited-∥∥𝜂subscript𝐠𝑡𝜂\left\lVert\eta\mathbf{g}_{t}\right\rVert\leq\eta∥ italic_η bold_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ ≤ italic_η, and projection to 𝒦𝒦\mathcal{K}caligraphic_K can only decrease distances (Fact 5). Otherwise, let it=i≠nsubscript𝑖𝑡𝑖𝑛i_{t}=i\neq nitalic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_i ≠ italic_n be the sampled index, using the common point 𝐱i∈𝒟∩𝒟′subscript𝐱𝑖𝒟superscript𝒟′\mathbf{x}_{i}\in\mathcal{D}\cap\mathcal{D}^{\prime}bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_D ∩ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Now, (14) follows from applying Lemma 11 with

𝐱←𝐳t−𝐱i,𝐲←𝐳t′−𝐱i,𝐮←𝐳t−𝐱i∥𝐳t−𝐱i∥,𝐯←𝐳t′−𝐱i∥𝐳t′−𝐱i∥.formulae-sequence←𝐱subscript𝐳𝑡subscript𝐱𝑖formulae-sequence←𝐲subscriptsuperscript𝐳′𝑡subscript𝐱𝑖formulae-sequence←𝐮subscript𝐳𝑡subscript𝐱𝑖delimited-∥∥subscript𝐳𝑡subscript𝐱𝑖←𝐯subscriptsuperscript𝐳′𝑡subscript𝐱𝑖delimited-∥∥subscriptsuperscript𝐳′𝑡subscript𝐱𝑖\mathbf{x}\leftarrow\mathbf{z}_{t}-\mathbf{x}_{i},\;\mathbf{y}\leftarrow% \mathbf{z}^{\prime}_{t}-\mathbf{x}_{i},\;\mathbf{u}\leftarrow\frac{\mathbf{z}_% {t}-\mathbf{x}_{i}}{\left\lVert\mathbf{z}_{t}-\mathbf{x}_{i}\right\rVert},\;% \mathbf{v}\leftarrow\frac{\mathbf{z}^{\prime}_{t}-\mathbf{x}_{i}}{\left\lVert% \mathbf{z}^{\prime}_{t}-\mathbf{x}_{i}\right\rVert}.bold_x ← bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_y ← bold_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_u ← divide start_ARG bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ∥ bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ end_ARG , bold_v ← divide start_ARG bold_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ∥ bold_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ end_ARG .

In particular, we have that ∥𝐱−𝐲∥=Φtdelimited-∥∥𝐱𝐲subscriptΦ𝑡\left\lVert\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{y}\right\rVert=\Phi_{t}∥ bold_x - bold_y ∥ = roman_Φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and ∥𝐱′−𝐲′∥≥Φt+1delimited-∥∥superscript𝐱′superscript𝐲′subscriptΦ𝑡1\left\lVert\mathbf{x}^{\prime}-\mathbf{y}^{\prime}\right\rVert\geq\Phi_{t+1}∥ bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - bold_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ ≥ roman_Φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (due to Fact 5), following notation from Lemma 11. We thus have Φt+1≤max⁡(Φt,3⁢η)subscriptΦ𝑡1subscriptΦ𝑡3𝜂\Phi_{t+1}\leq\max(\Phi_{t},3\eta)roman_Φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ roman_max ( roman_Φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , 3 italic_η ), which clearly also preserves (14) inductively. ∎

We can now conclude our privacy proof by applying composition to Corollary 1.

Lemma 12.

Let ϵ∈[0,1]italic-ϵ01\epsilon\in[0,1]italic_ϵ ∈ [ 0 , 1 ]. If 1ρ≥4⁢log⁡(2δ)ϵ2+2ϵ1𝜌42𝛿superscriptitalic-ϵ22italic-ϵ\frac{1}{\rho}\geq\frac{4\log(\frac{2}{\delta})}{\epsilon^{2}}+\frac{2}{\epsilon}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_ρ end_ARG ≥ divide start_ARG 4 roman_log ( divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG + divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_ϵ end_ARG, Algorithm 4 is (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)( italic_ϵ , italic_δ )-DP.

Proof.

We claim that Algorithm 4 satisfies ρ𝜌\rhoitalic_ρ-CDP, conditioned on ℐℐ\mathcal{I}caligraphic_I containing at most m𝑚mitalic_m choices of t𝑡titalic_t (we denote this conditional variant by 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A). By applying the second part of Fact 4 with α←2⁢log⁡(2δ)ϵ+1←𝛼22𝛿italic-ϵ1\alpha\leftarrow\frac{2\log(\frac{2}{\delta})}{\epsilon}+1italic_α ← divide start_ARG 2 roman_log ( divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_ϵ end_ARG + 1, this implies that 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A is (ϵ,δ2)italic-ϵ𝛿2(\epsilon,\frac{\delta}{2})( italic_ϵ , divide start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG )-DP. Because 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A has total variation distance at most δ8𝛿8\frac{\delta}{8}divide start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG start_ARG 8 end_ARG to Algorithm 4 due to Lemma 10, we conclude using Lemma 1 that Algorithm 4 is (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)( italic_ϵ , italic_δ )-DP.

We are left to show 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A satisfies ρ𝜌\rhoitalic_ρ-CDP. In fact, we will show that for all k∈[K]𝑘delimited-[]𝐾k\in[K]italic_k ∈ [ italic_K ], the output of the kthsuperscript𝑘thk^{\text{th}}italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT th end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT phase of 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A, i.e., 𝐱^(k)superscript^𝐱𝑘\hat{\mathbf{x}}^{(k)}over^ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, satisfies (169)−k⋅ρ2⋅superscript169𝑘𝜌2(\frac{16}{9})^{-k}\cdot\frac{\rho}{2}( divide start_ARG 16 end_ARG start_ARG 9 end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋅ divide start_ARG italic_ρ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG-CDP (treating the starting iterate 𝐳0(k)=𝐱^(k−1)superscriptsubscript𝐳0𝑘superscript^𝐱𝑘1\mathbf{z}_{0}^{(k)}=\hat{\mathbf{x}}^{(k-1)}bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = over^ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as fixed). Using composition of RDP (the first part of Fact 4), this implies 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A is ρ𝜌\rhoitalic_ρ-CDP as desired.

Finally, we bound the CDP of phase k∈[K]𝑘delimited-[]𝐾k\in[K]italic_k ∈ [ italic_K ]. Under 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A, we showed in Corollary 1 that all iterates of the kthsuperscript𝑘thk^{\text{th}}italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT th end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT phase have sensitivity ≤(2⁢m+1)⁢η(k)absent2𝑚1superscript𝜂𝑘\leq(2m+1)\eta^{(k)}≤ ( 2 italic_m + 1 ) italic_η start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Thus the average iterate 𝐱¯(k)superscript¯𝐱𝑘\bar{\mathbf{x}}^{(k)}over¯ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT also has sensitivity ≤(2⁢m+1)⁢η(k)absent2𝑚1superscript𝜂𝑘\leq(2m+1)\eta^{(k)}≤ ( 2 italic_m + 1 ) italic_η start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT by the triangle inequality. We can now bound the CDP of the kthsuperscript𝑘thk^{\text{th}}italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT th end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT phase using the third part of Fact 4:

((2⁢m+1)⁢η(k))22⁢(σ(k))2=((2⁢m+1)⁢η)2((2⁢m+1)⁢η)2⋅16−k⋅9k⋅ρ2≤(169)−k⋅ρ2.superscript2𝑚1superscript𝜂𝑘22superscriptsuperscript𝜎𝑘2⋅superscript2𝑚1𝜂2superscript2𝑚1𝜂2superscript16𝑘superscript9𝑘𝜌2⋅superscript169𝑘𝜌2\frac{((2m+1)\eta^{(k)})^{2}}{2(\sigma^{(k)})^{2}}=\frac{((2m+1)\eta)^{2}}{((2% m+1)\eta)^{2}}\cdot 16^{-k}\cdot 9^{k}\cdot\frac{\rho}{2}\leq\left(\frac{16}{9% }\right)^{-k}\cdot\frac{\rho}{2}.divide start_ARG ( ( 2 italic_m + 1 ) italic_η start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 ( italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG = divide start_ARG ( ( 2 italic_m + 1 ) italic_η ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ( ( 2 italic_m + 1 ) italic_η ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ⋅ 16 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋅ 9 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋅ divide start_ARG italic_ρ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ≤ ( divide start_ARG 16 end_ARG start_ARG 9 end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋅ divide start_ARG italic_ρ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG .

∎

4.2 Utility of Algorithm 4

We now analyze the error guarantees for Algorithm 4 on optimizing the geometric median objective f𝒟subscript𝑓𝒟f_{\mathcal{D}}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (3). We begin by providing a high-probability bound on the utility guarantees of each single phase.

Lemma 13.

Following notation of Algorithm 4, we have with probability ≥1−δ2absent1𝛿2\geq 1-\frac{\delta}{2}≥ 1 - divide start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG that

f𝒟⁢(𝐱¯(1)−f𝒟⁢(𝐱⋆)≤r^22⁢η(1)⁢T(1)+η(1)2+4⁢r^⁢2⁢log⁡(4⁢Kδ)T(1),f_{\mathcal{D}}(\bar{\mathbf{x}}^{(1})-f_{\mathcal{D}}(\mathbf{x}_{\star})\leq% \frac{\hat{r}^{2}}{2\eta^{(1)}T^{(1)}}+\frac{\eta^{(1)}}{2}+4\hat{r}\sqrt{% \frac{2\log(\frac{4K}{\delta})}{T^{(1)}}},italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over¯ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ≤ divide start_ARG over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_η start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG + divide start_ARG italic_η start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG + 4 over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 roman_log ( divide start_ARG 4 italic_K end_ARG start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG end_ARG ,

where 𝐱⋆:=argmin𝐱∈𝔹d⁢(𝐱¯,r^)⁢f⁢(𝐱)assignsubscript𝐱⋆subscriptargmin𝐱superscript𝔹𝑑¯𝐱^𝑟𝑓𝐱\mathbf{x}_{\star}:=\textup{argmin}_{\mathbf{x}\in\mathbb{B}^{d}(\bar{\mathbf{% x}},\hat{r})}f(\mathbf{x})bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := argmin start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x ∈ roman_𝔹 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( over¯ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG , over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( bold_x ), and

f𝒟⁢(𝐱¯(k))−f𝒟⁢(𝐱¯(k−1))≤2⁢(σ(k))2⁢d⁢log⁡(4⁢Kδ)η(k)⁢T(k)+η(k)2+8⁢σ(k)⁢log⁡(4⁢Kδ)⁢2⁢dT(k)⁢ for all ⁢2≤k≤K.subscript𝑓𝒟superscript¯𝐱𝑘subscript𝑓𝒟superscript¯𝐱𝑘12superscriptsuperscript𝜎𝑘2𝑑4𝐾𝛿superscript𝜂𝑘superscript𝑇𝑘superscript𝜂𝑘28superscript𝜎𝑘4𝐾𝛿2𝑑superscript𝑇𝑘 for all 2𝑘𝐾f_{\mathcal{D}}(\bar{\mathbf{x}}^{(k)})-f_{\mathcal{D}}(\bar{\mathbf{x}}^{(k-1% )})\leq\frac{2(\sigma^{(k)})^{2}d\log(\frac{4K}{\delta})}{\eta^{(k)}T^{(k)}}+% \frac{\eta^{(k)}}{2}+8\sigma^{(k)}\log\left(\frac{4K}{\delta}\right)\sqrt{% \frac{2d}{T^{(k)}}}\text{ for all }2\leq k\leq K.italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over¯ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over¯ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ≤ divide start_ARG 2 ( italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d roman_log ( divide start_ARG 4 italic_K end_ARG start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_η start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG + divide start_ARG italic_η start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG + 8 italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log ( divide start_ARG 4 italic_K end_ARG start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG ) square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 italic_d end_ARG start_ARG italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG end_ARG for all 2 ≤ italic_k ≤ italic_K .
Proof.

First, with probability ≥1−δ4absent1𝛿4\geq 1-\frac{\delta}{4}≥ 1 - divide start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG, we have

∥𝝃(k)∥≤2⁢σ(k)⁢d⁢log⁡(4⁢Kδ)⁢ for all ⁢k∈[K],delimited-∥∥superscript𝝃𝑘2superscript𝜎𝑘𝑑4𝐾𝛿 for all 𝑘delimited-[]𝐾\left\lVert\boldsymbol{\xi}^{(k)}\right\rVert\leq 2\sigma^{(k)}\sqrt{d\log% \left(\frac{4K}{\delta}\right)}\text{ for all }k\in[K],∥ bold_italic_ξ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ ≤ 2 italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT square-root start_ARG italic_d roman_log ( divide start_ARG 4 italic_K end_ARG start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG ) end_ARG for all italic_k ∈ [ italic_K ] ,

by standard Gaussian concentration. Thus, 𝐱¯(k−1)∈𝒦(k)superscript¯𝐱𝑘1superscript𝒦𝑘\bar{\mathbf{x}}^{(k-1)}\in\mathcal{K}^{(k)}over¯ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for all 2≤k≤K2𝑘𝐾2\leq k\leq K2 ≤ italic_k ≤ italic_K, and 𝐱⋆∈𝒦(1)subscript𝐱⋆superscript𝒦1\mathbf{x}_{\star}\in\mathcal{K}^{(1)}bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, except with probability δ4𝛿4\frac{\delta}{4}divide start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG. Next, consider the kthsuperscript𝑘thk^{\text{th}}italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT th end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT phase of Algorithm 4, and for some 0≤t<Tk0𝑡subscript𝑇𝑘0\leq t<T_{k}0 ≤ italic_t < italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, let us denote

𝐠~t(k):=𝐳t(k)−𝐱i∥𝐳t(k)−𝐱i∥assignsuperscriptsubscript~𝐠𝑡𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐳𝑡𝑘subscript𝐱𝑖delimited-∥∥superscriptsubscript𝐳𝑡𝑘subscript𝐱𝑖\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{t}^{(k)}:=\frac{\mathbf{z}_{t}^{(k)}-\mathbf{x}_{i}}{\left% \lVert\mathbf{z}_{t}^{(k)}-\mathbf{x}_{i}\right\rVert}over~ start_ARG bold_g end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := divide start_ARG bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ∥ bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ end_ARG

where i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n]italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ] is the random index sampled on Line 12 in the tthsuperscript𝑡tht^{\text{th}}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT th end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT iteration of phase k𝑘kitalic_k. We also denote
